content:
Wow, what a piece of trash this so called site has become. I just closed my 17+ year old account out of disgust.

My problem, the fake reviews, so called vine program, and tons of fake ass nonsense Amazon has going on. I got an email from at least one honest person at Amazon referring to"testing" certain accounts and voting features of "certain accounts". Which was part of my complaint. 

Then after all of this started they started deleting some of my reviews without even telling me! Not letting me edit my reviews. Things got completely stupid with how they were manipulating my account, and maintained the ENTIRE time they were not.

I keep chuckling at one of my phone calls in the middle of this sh!tshow. This guy kept saying, I'm going to hang up if you don't stop swearing. But I had not sworn. Normally my talk is peppered with extremely colorful language, to say it sweetly. So I very clearly am aware while talking to any support person about my language. F##king idiot. 

Basically there is some major BS going on and when I directly called them out they continued to lie and tell me to clear my cache, and other insults to my intelligence, not to mention my email PROOF ACKNOWLEDGING they were doing something. I got nowhere with the BBB complaint. So I finally closed my very old account out of pure digust and frustration. 

My advice, run every product URL through fakespot.com first before purchasing anything else! Will save some major headaches, but unfortunately not all. Good luck with these jokers and their "two day shipping". Which rarely is ever really two days. Amazon, go f##k yourself. I say that from a place of deep respect.
title: “Wtf happened to this company?”

content:
I am a Prime Amazon Member. I ordered a new $1300.00 TV that I found on Amazon which was promised to be delivered "next day" on July 6, 2016. The date was updated to July 7, 2016 online when I checked the status online. I called and was told that it would definitely be delivered on July 7th and that Amazon would refund my next day shipping. I waited all day on July 7th for the TV. The TV never arrived. I went online and it said that it was coming by MAIL and that it was in transit! I called Amazon and asked how in the world could they guarantee ANYTHING sent by MAIL to be delivered the following day...and how could they send something so expensive and fragile BY MAIL? They had no answer. The agent put me on hold and said that she would call the USPS about the delivery. She came back online and said that she had spoken with the USPS and had been told it would be delivered by 3:00 p.m. She told me that she would call me back at 4:00 p.m. to confirm the delivery. At 4:20 p.m., I had no TV and no call from Amazon. So, I called Amazon. All the agent could tell me was that, in checking his tracking information, he could see the TV was "in transit." I told him that I KNEW that much as I could see it when I looked myself. He told me at that point that the TV would "probably come tomorrow or the next day." I told him that I had reserved a man to come out to mount my TV based upon Amazon's "guarantee" and all he could say was, "I'm sorry. I know you are frustrated." At that point I told him to cancel the order and I would go to Best Buy and get the TV there for the same price. He told me that he canceled the order. I also told him to cancel my Prime Membership as well. I am done with Amazon and their delivery "guarantee" days which, obviously, mean nothing at all. 

UPDATE: The Amazon Representative did not cancel the orde and it arrived the next day by mail carrier. I refused the delivery as I had already purchased the same TV from Best Buy the night before. The ironic thing about that was when the mailed TV arrived, the guy was at my home mounting the one I had bought at Best Buy! I'm still waiting for my refund from Amazon on my credit card of over $1300.00 and filed a dispute with AMEX just in case. Amazon says it can take up to two weeks to get the money refunded as returning the TV can take that long to get to them. They did give me $100.00 on my AMEX as a "goodwill" gesture for all the issues with this order. The Amazon representative also did not cancel my Prime as I had asked them to do. I seriously think that their representatives say "Yes!" To just about everything and understand very, very little English.
title: “Do not count upon "Guaranteed Delivery Dates"”

content: My wife and I have been consistent Amazon customers for many years.  Recently, a good friend of ours wrote and published a book, which was--and is--marketed on Amazon.  We bought several copies from Amazon, gave some to friends, and each read our own copy.  Then, we each posted a review on Amazon.  Our reviews were favorable because the book is very well written, and a lot of fun.  However, Amazon chose to delete both our reviews because they deemed them to be "too favorable."  When my wife called them, they refused to reinstate the reviews, and were arrogant, condescending and borderline rude.  Their attitude is unacceptable.  We will be avoiding the site whenever possible from now on.  I have made two purchases online since, but used Amazon only to identify original sellers, then I go directly to them, bypassing Amazon.
title: “Devious and insulting”

content: I have never had such bad experience with Amazon in my life. Being a very big Amazon shopper, since their inception, I've dealt with many issues along the way that have been carefully and gracefully dealt with by their once STELLAR customer service reps providing excellent customer service. Recently, I placed an order for an item that I needed for a specific event, the item came on time, it was defective (sold and fulfilled by Amazon LLC). The customer service rep assured me that they would replace the item before my dinner party and then placed a new order for with overnight shipping at no cost also through Amazon LLC. Long story short, the item never came, turns out the rep had put an order in for the item on a 0 stock - I was never notified, and they did nothing at all to remedy their giant mistake. I was offered only to cancel my order for a full refund. We found a replacement item from a third party on Amazon for a higher price and they would not even price match the lower price I had paid for the same items sold through Amazon LLC. I will no longer be shopping with Amazon, steep steep decline in my eyes. Customer service is everything. If it is your fault, especially, you need to do something about it.
title: “Customer Service Declined Majorly”

content: I had purchased a Toshiba  620 DVD/VHS Recorder. it arrived filthy, completely unusable and  broken. I contacted Amazon and they gave me the go ahead to return it to the seller for a full refund. I also contacted Ace Internet Solutions, Inc. and was assured that I would receive a refund in full, which included the return shipping that I had to pay for out of my own pocket. For some unknown reason, Amazon refused to give me the refund that I am entitled to. I contacted Amazon via email several times and by phone as well. Amazon's Customer Service agreed that since I have proof that this piece of garbage is in  Ace's possession along with my money - $152.00, that I am indeed entitled to a full refund. Instead, Amazon sent me an email stating that they were not going to give me a refund. I contacted Ace many time, was repeatedly promised a refund and never received anything. I reported Ace to the BBB, the USPS Mail Order Fraud Dept. and several other consumer fraud organizations. Of course, Ace did not respond to anyone. And I am out $152.00 and no merchandise. I'm going to continue to report Ace and Amazon for mail order fraud to every organization that deals with this. I may never see my money, but I can make things miserable for both and perhaps prevent someone else from this nasty situation.
title: “Amazon Allowed Unscrupulous Seller To Rip Me Off”

content: I went to the amazon site to buy a replacement catalytic converter for my vehicle to meet California emission standards. The site noted the converter would fit my vehicle. I ordered it, had it welded in place, and went for a smog test. It failed, and the emissions were 4 times higher with this new cat as compared to the old one. After further research, the converter Amazon noted for fitting my vehicle was incorrect. They allowed me to return it, but I had already spent the price of the converter on the installation and smog test. The vehicle is now listed as a gross polluter. WOW! GARBAGE IN GARBAGE OUT!
title: “BEWARE OF AUTO PARTS ON AMAZON”

content:
Amazon was great. Now it is terrible.

A. They have become very sneaky, with a complicated order procedure that tries to trick you into signing up for Amazon Prime (my 91-year-old mother was a victim) by making the buttons for that bright orange, as if that is the default for ordering. The "free shipping" now is also obfuscated: It used to be at the top, now is in with "Free Shipping! - (if you get our credit card)". "Amazon Pantry" as well--what is that? Complicated. Sometimes I choose an item and it comes up in the cart that I ordered two (no, I didn't click twice).  Sneaky. Don't  like it at all. Used to be simple and quick.

B. Shipping is now much less reliable, time-wise. They have taken to using the post office, which does not re-deliver, and tracking delivery dates are no longer accurate a lot of the time.

C. Free shipping was $25 minimum order, then $35, now--apparently--$49.

D. Aren't so great to their employees, from what I understand. I always look for an alternative (B&H for electronics, for instance).

E. Amazon-shipped items still pretty reliable, but I have had increasing problems with outside store orders. Seems like they don't vet the stores so well anymore. I notice that many Amazon-affiliated stores are rated badly by Resellerratings.

F. Customer service is like communicating with robots (which may be what you are doing). Returns have been fine for me, however.

Amazon needs to take a page from Costco, which has held its quality--and continued to make a good profit--even though it is at the top in its field and treats its employees very well. I will avoid Amazon whenever possible.
title: “Started out good; get worse every year”

content:
Since January of 2014 to date, March 2016, we have placed 207 orders with Amazon.  It has been, until now, an extraordinarily good experience.  We have a great deal of respect for Mr. Bezos and what he has done.  This particular experience, however, was awful!  I thought that, since we had faired so well, maybe a larger item would work too; so, we ordered this Samsung dishwasher with installation and removal of the old washer.  Words fail me.  I had planned to aggregate all of the failures and miscommunications of this transaction like some prosecutor in a courtroom for others to read, but I am tired of thinking of it.  So, here goes with an unstudied, less calculated recap:  from the inception of the order we received multiple e-mailed correspondence as to the delivery of the product and the delivery of the ordered installation from at least four disparate sources.  There have been at least six different business entities and Amazon agents involved in the entire process: (i) Plessers, whoever that is; (ii) AM Home Installation, or something like that; (iii) Amazon, of course, who by the way disavow any responsibility once the money has changed hands, choosing rather to turn both the work and all appeals for help over to various other amorphous agencies; (iv) Nathan at 800.344.4856  I have no idea how I came to be in touch with him, but at least to his credit he revealed surprise at how the order had aged; (v) some man from New York named Miguel Santos, who reluctantly later identified his agency as Infinite Installations and himself as customer service agent for Amazon, that I talked to with no good outcome (At one point, Mr. Santos sent me an e-mail with an Amazon telephone number to call for customer service; it turned out to be a non-working number); and not least (vi) the named agent now representing Amazon for the claim.  From the beginning delivery was promised in the e-mails, but the installation dates supplied by each mail preceded the delivery date stipulated in the respective communication!  In an e-mailed response, I asked how you could install a product not yet delivered, but never got an answer to that or any other question.  With each mail, the delivery-install dates kept changing, each time with an install date which post-dated the delivery date!  Finally, this AM company arrived 5 hours beyond the promised four hour window.  I let the guy come into my home with the machine.  He was clearly harried and seemed uncertain of himself.  He brought the new machine into my home, banging our custom front door as he entered.  When the subject of removal of the old dishwasher came up, the guy said they were not responsible for removal of the old washer.  NOTE:  THIS WAS ONE OF THE IMPORTANT PARTS OF THE AGREEMENT WE ENTERED WITH AMAZON!  I then refused delivery and asked him to leave our home.  At first he wouldnt leave.  I insisted that he go.  Miserable experience!  The left hand seemed not to know that the right hand even existed, much less what it was doing.

They have now charged us $600 and left us to deal with another third party for ostensible resolution, bringing the total of different involved parties to at least six.  To anyone who might say to us that we should have known better, this is Amazon, we would say, you are absolutely right.  We should have known better.  We know now.  Small purchases have been great for us, and we will continue to buy these items; we will avoid complex buys in the future, however simply they are presented.

P.S.
I was interested in seeing what kind of response we might get from other Amazon customers.  In the main, I agree with what I have read:  for small items, Amazon is great!  Could not agree more fully.  Thus far, however, no one has shared an experience substantially similar to ours that went well for them.  Buying a $1200 dishwasher and having it installed in your home is not like buying a small commodity.  Our experience was confusing and very disappointing.  Amazon did not act as a third party overseeing the process to ensure good service.  This is simply not true.

P.S. (160407)
We have the final disposition of this matter.  We originally paid Amazon $1,131.00; of that amount Amazon returned to us $1,083.40, keeping $226.20.

Post-Script #3 (160503)
Before finding SiteJabber and making this post, I tried to first post this review on Amazon. Someone who did not identify themselves denied the review; their only comment lay in the following excerpt with quotation marks outlying:   "We have a great deal of respect for Mr. Bezos and what he has done."  The intimation from this censor(s) seemed to be, we only accept complimentary reviews, seemingly suggesting that it would be ok for me to say nice things about them.  That response set me on this quest.
title: “PURCHASE REVIEW:  DISHWASHER WITH INSTALLATION”

 Simple. Now I'm stuck with needing to order from amazon as they have the easiest access to products I like, and not wanting to give them any more $. As long as I make simple orders, I think it'll be ok......Never want to call in ever again.

content: Amazon does get traffic but surely dont use them as your only channel.  Theres been horror stories from large sellers.  Amazon has a flawed process in place for follow up if you do get kicked off as a seller.  So you fill out all this paperwork then they still turn you down to be a seller again.  When I was on a buyer could open up a case for say a defective product, but he opened up 3 cases for the same product and got me kicked off because it made my defect numbers too high,  So if your an Amazon seller be very careful not to make them your only distribution channel as if and when they kick you off  they wont even answer your messages.  To add insult to injury then they hold your money owed to you hostage for at least a month to 6 weeks before they will release it. I say avoid Amazon  as they compete against their sellers as well. Did you know you cannot leave feedback for Amazon the company when you buy something direct from them?  Its no surprise because they dont want you leaving them bad feedback, sounds like a double standard to me.

content: Twice I've received used merchandise (directly) from Amazon.com, when it was supposed to be new. In a recent case, Amazon sent a used, defective backup camera system for Recreational Vehicle (RV), then replaced it with a 2nd defective unit. The instructions were useless. I cobbled together one working unit and returned the non-working parts. I installed the unit on my RV, which involved drilling holes in the body. Then I discovered that the camera had a condensation problem that arose whenever the camera was on for more than 15 seconds. I tried to contact the company (Ducooler and Xie Ju Ming) but their website was inactive. You can type them a support email, but you can never send it :-(   . Amazon agreed to take back the 2nd unit. When I sent it to Amazon, they charged me a $15.20 "restocking fee".   This is blatant fraud, as the unit was defective. Clearly Amazon intends to send it to yet another victim. Perhaps they hope that someone will pay for it, be confused by it, and not return it. Fraud, Fraud, Fraud.   I replied to the Amazon email telling me that they were "restocking" it, but it bounced. Their email wasn't even signed by a person. I disputed the insufficient refund with the credit card company and have no doubt that the dispute will stick, given the circumstances. Huge amount of time spent; some phone calls over 1 hour. Many emails sent.  Bottom line is: Avoid Amazon.com, and if you do receive used merchandise instead of new merchandise, return it immediately. Don't waste time trying to make it work....chances are that it has already been returned by someone else.
title: “amazon shipping used merchandise as new”

content: I used to love amazon.  It was great for buying and selling textbooks as well as buying other things at competitive prices.  Over the last year, however, I have become very disappointed with the site.  I spent hours Christmas shopping trying to find items that would fulfill a $25 credit for a "gift" item that my daughter really wanted.  The qualifying items were considerably more expensive than other sellers had them for, and I ended up spending a lot more than I wanted and I ended up with a DVD that will not play on US players.  Just recently, I tried to sell a few things on amazon.  I couldn't log into my seller account and had to sign up for a professional account which costs $39 a month.  I didn't know I could sign up for an individual account and sell my items that way.  Long story short, I HAD to deactivate my account because I didn't have the correct tax or business info to have a professional account.  Now I can't sell on amazon again unless I create a new account.  I can't even cancel/terminate my existing account without contacting customer service.  I can't even find the number to contact them to do so.  The whole website has become so user unfriendly and not worth my time to continue to shop through them.  I never liked ebay, but I'm thinking I will switch back to shopping there because amazon has just gotten too greedy and doesn't really care about consumer needs anymore.
title: “Used to be a great site.... not anymore”

content:
That is the Amazon site where usually they sell the used goods. Based on my experience they seem to turnaround returned goods (which may have been returned for being defective another reason to avoid buying from there) and resell them without checking them out first. 

I bought a Asus Flip chromebook, used like new (just described the condition of the box claiming it was unopened) but right after I took it out of the box the computer acted strangely. It was scroll, font would change size, picture would shake without  me even touching it!!  I started a return request stating that it was defective and gave all the above reasons and stated that it was like it was possessed and I was afraid of it!  

I usually don't check my invoices just expecting them to get it right on the refund, but for some reason I DID check and saw that they charged me the return shipping and changed the reason for return from defective product (where customer does NOT get charged for the return)  to buyer wanted to return reason (where you DO get charged.)  I immediately notified Amazon and they refunded the charges but even though you can see how many stars the "warehouse' gets you can NOT read the reviews at to why, you click onto that it just brings you to an Amazon fact page unlike the private sellers where you can read what the customers say about them and AW's rating is NOT high, 84%.  The only review that you can see me write was about the product itself, so I would advise NOT EVER to buy ANYthing from Amazon Warehouse, if you buy it used, buy from private seller.
title: “Beware of buying from Amazon Warehouse...”

content:
I've enjoyed many years of great service with Amazon. The few minor problems I've encountered through the years were solved fast and efficiently by their Customer Support Team. Free standard shipping during this time was 5 to 7 days. It seems that with the introduction of "Prime" free standard shipping now takes 7 to 12 days. The last three items I've ordered took the proverbial slow boat to Missouri. One package took 5 days to get from Texas to Missouri. Then while tracking the package it was delayed for 5 days at a facility close to me. A helpful Amazon Rep had it delivered the next day. Ink for my printer has taken 7 days to get halfway from California to Missouri! I could walk faster than that! My impression is that those of us that use free shipping will be penalized. If poor shipping practices don't affect you, by all means continue to shop at Amazon.

Stewart C. Hagerman

Member: American Mensa Society
title: “RATING FOR AMAZON SHIPPING PRACTICES ONLY”

http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/81PhzkBnR6L._SL1500_.jpg

I ordered this item 2 weeks ago, and hopes to receive it before christmas in order to gift wrap it. I just found out today at 6am EST that AMAZON cancelled the order due to product availability. I called customer service to request why it was available 2 weeks ago and why I'm just now finding out about this being cancelled. The SUPERVISOR said sorry the orders are based on priority and told me to reorder it through another seller, and hope that I receive it by Christmas, after I explained this was not an issue she stated she attempted to call a 3rd party vendor to get one directly shipped to me. But all she really did was disconnect the phone after an hour and 20 mins waiting with multiple hold times. This was shocking to have happen, but even more shocking is that when I called right back I was just told that I could reorder it and get a gift card. As this is their issue I feel like they need to reorder it at no cost to me and send it next day. The resolution was to close my account with amazon. This was the most poor customer service I have ever received. I will no longer do business AMAZON. Amazon is horrible at resolving in customers favor, even when they know that they are dead wrong. Furthermore, I will be canceling my chase amazon card due to this poor inconvenience and they didn't even seem to care. Its truly sad.
title: “1:30 mins for a order they cancelled”

content:
Amazon is demonstrating some true Holiday spirit with deceptive promotional offerings.  So deceptive their own support people don't understand it.

Watch out.  Amazon will offer you $5.99 for Amazon Pantry items in exchange for accepting slower shipping options. 

After 3 phone calls and nearly 1.5 hours on the phone, Amazon support was finally able to explain it.

It's only works for a very limited number of grocery items that Amazon sells directly themselves.  You'll know because "the item will be marked as an Amazon Pantry item."

So I got two credits.  About $10.  I figured I would at least buy an item for free.  I chose Vanilla extract for about $10.  However, it was going to cost me $10 to get it.  Doesn't make sense, right?  Well, you can only use one credit at a time.  So that means I can only use $5 to buy the $10 item.  Then for any "pantry" items that Amazon sells you are charged $5 for a "boxing fee."  Usually this is called shipping, and since I am an Amazon Prime Member, I expected my shipping would be free.  Not the case.  So in the end it would cost me $10 to get a $10 item as an Amazon Prime member, even with a $10 credit.
title: “Sleezy Marketing Practices”

content:
Our last 3 orders, within 2 months, with Amazon have been total disasters. We pay for prime shipping and our order was a month late even though they show it in stock.
The other 2 were Warehouse Deals. The first time I ordered a Polywood teal patio table. I received an ugly dark green rocking chair. Many emails and time wasted to resolve this to our satisfaction. Initially they offered free shipping...what? already pay for that.
The 3rd order was a dark brown, nautical Polywood set for our condo in FL.(we do not live in FL) This was handled through freight shipping where they dump it in the parking lot so I had to pay a person to take it up to our condo and assemble it. BUT, they shipped a light colored, BAR HEIGHT set. Nothing like what I ordered!!Useless to us. They will NOT replace it and tell me Warehouse Deals is a third party seller, trying to divert the blame. We can not disassemble it or waste more money and time paying another person to wait for a return pick up. STUCK AGAIN.  Will not buy from them EVER AGAIN!  Beware when you buy a so called WAREHOUSE DEAL,  that you can waste your time, money, and in the end receive the poorest customer service on the face of this planet. Call centers in India. All that they do is apologize. Never a solution to the problem.
title: “BEWARE of Amazon Warehouse Deals! BATE & SWITCH, twice!NO SERVICE!”

content: I ordered from an Amazon marketplace seller and was later told by email the item was not in stock and wouldn't be for a long time. I was given instructions for cancelling which I followed. Much later they charged my card and sent the item after I'd bought it elsewhere. They made me jump though a bunch of hoops to return it and then charged a 15% re-stocking fee. I complained to them and Amazon. Both said I had gotten the item so that was it. The package came from Overstock, not the seller. These marketplace sellers apparently merely put on a listing, jack up the price, order from somewhere else and apparently have no control over the stock info or the orders. The item was cheaper directly from Overstock and even cheaper ordered from Walmart. My advice is don't order from marketplace sellers unless it will be fulfilled by Amazon.
title: “Don't use Amazon marketplace unless "fulfilled by Amazon"”

content: Amazon purchased audible.com and their actions have been very unethical in sharing Amazon account information with Audible in order to continue to debit accounts after members have cancelled memberships and/or their debit cards. DELETE your credit/debit card numbers from your Amazon account. While investigating i found that Amazon will try any account that you have ever used (if you haven't actually gone into account management and manually deleted them) if the card you authorized them to use is expired, cancelled, or otherwise not usable. I had used my mothers credit account at one point in time (as authorized) and would have been appalled had they started using her account for my husbands audible membership (although he never even signed up for a membership). It makes me wonder if they were able to use my amazon account info to pay for my husbands audible account, what is to stop them from getting into her amazon account and debit other accounts. The whole thing is mind boggling to me that they somehow got into my amazon account to pay his audible account and it seems like this Audible purchase by Amazon could have been for this express purpose to pursue other income opportunities by unsuspecting customers.
title: “Beware”

content: Unreliable and arrogant. These words describe what United Graphics has now become. I first contracted with UGI in 2009, and I found it to be timely and honest. My most recent experience with them has proven how this company has lost its way. I was told by a customer service representative named Abell that 575 books would be shipped the first Thursday in June for next-day delivery. I even paid money to have this shipment guaranteed. The next day, she calls saying that the shipment had not gone out, claiming that a printing machine had broken, even though she said that the books were being bound two days before. I then requested that one box of 56 books be shipped for Saturday, in time for a book fair I was working that weekend. She agreed, and then gave me the UPS tracking number. When I checked ups.com that night, the next-day shipment had been incorrectly processed for Monday, not Saturday morning. UGI then insults me further by offering me a five-percent credit -- credit...as if I'm going to use them again! -- on the job. Somewhere, this company has lost its dedication to customer service, honesty, and respect for its customers. Do yourself and your project a favor and avoid this company
title: “United Graphics is now dishonest, unreliable and arrogant”

Ordered a textbook for my daughter from Amazon.  It began falling apart after 5 weeks...pages falling out everywhere, binding breaking down.  First time I contacted Amazon they said I could order another one and they would send me a return label so I could return the first book for a full refund.  Liars!  Got an email saying their "A to Z Guarantee Team" had decided that I waited too long (more than 2 weeks) to claim the book was defective.  So it's my fault that the book took 5 weeks to fall apart instead of 2??  Appealed their decision, was turned down again.  They put a block on my emails asking for reconsideration!

I will never shop Amazon again unless I absolutely have to.  I should have bought the book at my community college bookstore, where they have some ethics and would have happily helped me return the book for a refund.

content: I purchase and have purchased many items from Amzon on a weekly basis, I am a Prime member, and have done most of my shopping through Amazon due to their past return policy.  I did not realize that Amazon Prime orders had a strict 30 day return policy now.  I purchased three pairs of shoes through Amazon Prime and they did not arrive in time for me to take on my trip.  When I arrived back from my trip, the shoes were not returnable even though they did not arrive on time to be useful to me.  In the future, I will not buy ANYTHING that I have to try on or that I am planning to take on a trip through Amazon.  You cannot count on the Prime shipping and with the 30 day policy, I am better off going through a Department Store like Macy's that will give me a full refund or store credit ANYTIME after purchase.

content:
Amazon.com's site promised I would get a phone call in 1 minute when I needed help sending an item I added to someone's gift list.  They did not call in over 25 HOURS despite feedback I would get a call within 1 minute.  They later refused to allow me to add a gift to someone's wish list and send it to them.  My crime was wanting to send a Teddy Bear.

I had spent hours on Amazon's site trying to add and then order a gift for an online friend who's address is known to Amazon via their wish list, in fact I had already ordered one item that was delivered so I couldn't understand why I could not get their site to work a second time.

When I finally spoke to someone in customer service from the "wish list" department I was told that I can not add something to someone's wish list and send it to them.  If that is the case, why do they even allow consumers to add "gift ideas" to the friend's wish list profile if you can't buy them?

They told me it was because the recipient might want to return the gift, but I'm the customer, not the gift recipient.  It's my money and I am buying a gift, not an item the recipient can return and get money in return.

The only rationale I can think of is due to sending inappropriate gifts, however I was trying to send a Teddy Bear for a friend, to help in a trying time.  Amazon's employee had ZERO interest in trying to understand.  Stupid policy is what we have so we're going to follow it.  That should be their Slogan.

What is perhaps most ironic about the email I received from Amazon in response to my complaint is the last line of Amazon's email:

"Your feedback is helping us build Earth's Most Customer-Centric Company."

This has to be the biggest lie I've seen advertised by a company in years.  What an absolutely horrible company to do business with.
title: “Amazon, no customer service and won't allow you to send gifts you add to a wish list.”

content: I have shopped Amazon many times and have always been happy with it. I also sometimes have to rely on online shopping like Amazon because I am still recovering from cancer, and am not always able to jump in the car and drive a half hour to a major chain store to get what I need. So when I tried the new Prime Pantry I had high expectations of what it's quality would be, and was hopeful in it being a good resource for me. I ordered items that were canned and items in boxes, that I would normally buy in the grocery store, and thought I was getting a deal with such a decent price, but when I received my box of items I was really disappointed. First of all, the cans were almost all dented. Not normally a big deal, but there was never any mention of denting on the site, and Amazon is usually particular about making an honest accounting of the condition of items. The cans were packed loosely into the box with the boxes of food and pasta so they caused plenty of damage while getting bounced around by the postal service. The shipping box was split into 2 sides, but the cans were scattered so there were several on both sides so NONE of the boxed food was safe from damage. Some items were so damaged that they were leaking, and had to be thrown out. Since the service, Prime Pantry, shows you how full a box is when you are ordering, I was confused why there was so much looseness in the shipping box, when the service said the box was 99% full, when I ordered. I have alerted them to my disappointment, and they refunded my money in full. However, this service is not one that I am eager to give another try. I told Amazon that I would rather shop at the grocery store, and spend extra money, than use this service again and roll the dice on what I may have to throw out from damage. I do not want to go through this every time I get a box from them that is packed like the people working there are living brain donors. Who wants to deal with that?!
title: “Amazon Prime Pantry is a Pain in the A&%!”

content: Amazon.com makes money by selling and promoting products.  If you give a product an honest review that is negative, Amazon will absolutely censor and suppress it.  That's totally dishonest.  On the other hand, most of the product ratings and reviews at Amazon's website are obviously phony, superficial and meaningless.  So much for integrity, which just isn't part of Amazon.com.  And, if a product you buy at Amazon harms you, you will learn that Amazon will take no responsibility for the material nondisclosures that caused you to erroneously buy the harmful product, and they will laugh and sneer at your injury.  That's how egregiously arrogant the Amazon employees/ownership really are. They claim to be the Largest Online Retailer in North America, but just don't ask them to be accountable!  Goodness, Amazon.com takes all the praise and none of the problems. So, just hope you don't get harmed by anything you buy at Amazon.  By the way, Amazon knows the product reviews and ratings are mostly fake and phony.  I wonder how many of the reviewers for Amazon on SiteJabber are fakes.  When I read a review that is shallow and superficial and just says "Amazon is wonderful"/5 stars, I know it's fake.  According to Amazon, even though you believe they are selling you the product on their website, taking your money, handling the order, guaranteeing the order and within the chain of sellers, they are not the seller, so they fraudulently justify their own lies that they have absolutely no obligation or responsibility.

content:
I'm going to place the blame for Audible's rotten service and sloppily coded website to the REAL culprits.  Amazon has been doing the same sort of economic cannibalism that seems to afflict most of Corporate America.  They don't compete, they EAT their competition.  Then leave we the people to deal with the residue.
I studiously avoid buying anything from Amazon and so should anyone who cares about what's wrong with our economy.
Choice is power.  When our choices disappear we get monopolies charging whatever they please and ignoring any legitimate complaint or just humouring the complainants so they'll go away.
I don't care who's doing it.  It's bad for us in the near and far term.
I don't care how rich it's made Mr. Bezos.  He's still one of our Public Enemies in economic terms.

Edgar W. Webb
edgarwwebb@gmail.com

content: On Friday, April 17, 2015 before 8:00am, I placed 2 orders and paid additional money for next day delivery. Late Friday evening I received an email from Amazon that the items would be delivered at 8pm Saturday evening.  As luck would have it, the items did not arrive. I contacted Amazon's Customer Service department shortly after 8pm Saturday evening. I spoke with a first line representative, a supervisor and manager to explain that my shipments never arrived which were gifts for my niece's birthday party on Saturday.  I also explained that my niece waited all day to receive her gifts and was excited about her special day.  All 3 Amazon representatives told me that the delivery date and time were estimates, and that the items would arrive on Monday, April 20. Nowhere did it mention that the overnight shipping was an estimate.  The reason I asked for a manager is because the supervisor also said, "sometimes we get disappointed." This was unacceptable! I told her that adults understand, but children do not. Children are kids for a short time and look forward to birthdays and holidays. Had I known on Friday morning when I placed the order that delivery was going to be at 8pm not earlier in the day, I would have cancelled the order.  Such information was sent via email late Friday evening and should have been noted during the ordering process. A delivery time should be available when an order is placed.  Additionally, when the packages did not arrive by 8pm Saturday evening, I only learned by calling Amazon customer service that the packages would be delivered on Monday. Amazon did not take the initiative to notify me of the delayed deliveries. Had I known that the guaranteed delivery date which I paid additional shipping cost for had changed, I would have gone shopping either Friday or Saturday with my niece for her gifts. The Amazon representatives were insensitive to the situation and made excuses for the company. Their generous offer was to refund the guaranteed overnight shipping cost. Meanwhile, I still have no gifts for my niece. To say the least, I am extremely disappointed with my overall Amazon experience.
title: “Don't do it...”

content:
In 2014- based on the advertisement-and my conversation with their customer service representative- I bought from Amazon- a 10 inch foam mattress- made by Sleep Well.
I was deployed for active military duty-and upon my return- I attempted to buy a frame.
I was now told that any frame I bought-would require a wooden plywood-to be placed between the frame and mattress- to ensure the warranty- and not injure the sleeper. I contacted Amazon- and after they read the advertisement- we filed an A-Z Complaint. I never heard from anyone- besides my refund was denied. Meanwhile I spoke to Sleep Well-and under the circumstances they were sending me a replacement mattress. Amazon wrote me a thank you letter- and was sending it up via Corporate- because any frame sold by Amazon-made by Olee-Zanus etc- approximately 100 frames- are all falsely advertised- and all require that plywood board to be paced on the frame- this is no-where mentioned in any of their ads- so all 100 advertisements for these frames would have to be revised.
Meanwhile A-Z without talking to me about anything denied my claim- even though Sleep Well was willing to replace the damaged mattress. At no charge.
I asked Amazon to compensate me-for all the time-aggravation-and work that I performed- that permitted their organization to send this information up the ladder to Corporate-so that all these bed frames would have to be revised and corrected.
I asked for compensation-for all my time and work- in the form of a metal frame-that holds a box spring- as to ensure the 10 year warranty of the mattress. After being put on hold for over 1 hour- so Indian Supervisor came back- and was rather rude- and objected in doing anything besides denying my claim.
I have forwarded all these letters to Mr. Bezos- of course I don't expect him to respond- but possibly one of his subordinates after reading this fiasco- would make things right.
In the last year- the Amazon catch phrase has become- if your not happy- return the product-and we shall provide you with a full refund. Great business practice. Must be nice when you are a monopoly.
title: “False Advertising- A-Z Complaint Departnent A Sham”

content:
There are millions of people who only have one computer in their home, or uses the same account to shop with, and when they are buying a gift for someone they don't want them to see the recommendation, because it is based on what you viewed. Anyone else who uses the computer and goes to Amazon can see what you are looking at. And you can't turn that feature off.  

And like most big companies today; there is nobody you can talk to; they simply don't want to hear about any customer complaints, unless it's on a list they provide. 

They are also not cheap.

The other day I was going to order a basketball pump from them; it was $4.95; with $6.75 shipping. I went to E-bay found the same pump, for the same price from a 5 star dealer, and the shipping was free. The Amazon seller wanted more for shipping, and handling then the item cost. 

Amazon only gives you free shipping if you spend over $35.00. In my book that makes them yet another Corporate giant trying to get more out of you, then you should have to pay.  

There are better deals on E-Bay then these rip off artists are trying to scam you with.

They are sneaky!

My wife ordered a vest for me on their website. There was no mention that this vest was coming from China until after you place your order. 

The vest cost $20.00 with shipping. What they don't mention is that if it doesn't fit, like mine didn't; it would cost you $20.00 to send it back to China. I myself would call that deceptive practices. They knew how much it would cost to return this item; but they didn't tell you!

Bottom line; you can get the same stuff on E-Bay that you can get from Amazon, from some honest Mom, and Pop business, often with free shipping. All you have to do is look at the customer reviews of that business. Only deal with the good ones! 

As for Amazon; well I've bought stuff from this company for at least 10-years, but after this last rip off purchase, They can kiss my you no what!
title: “They could care less about you.”

content:
You know this is the worst buying experience I have had in my entire life and I'm 63 yrs old. I have had better experiences buy a used car then it was dealing with Amazon on this. First off I will never ever purchase another product from any of amazon's affiliates. 
When you sell a product you ought to have someone there that can answer questions on what the products limits are. I called amazon before I purchased this unit and the person could tell my absolutely nothing on what the product could do. Explained to the person what I was going to use the product for and they said it would do just fine. I also called the manufacturer to see what they said about it too and was told the very same thing. After I had 2 units both of them damaged and had to be repaired by me to make it look decent. Took me probably 2 hours to straighten the sleeves on the units. Without any compensation whatsoever for doing it. I could have called the service center and had them come out and fix it I guess but of course the nearest one is 4 hours away and that would have cost you guys a bunch of money but I fixed them myself.
The worst thing about this whole deal is I bought the unit for a new building and there was a hole cut in my wall to fit this unit. Now when I find out the unit isn't anything close to what I need to do the job I wanted it to.
I have a hole in my wall where a different product will not fit. So I have to have the contractor of the building to come out and replace a bunch of wains coating and insulation. This was not free so I not only did all the repairs on the unit taking it in and out of the building several times I had to get my building fixed. 
And then the returning of the product was another thing. You advertise this unit as being 150 lbs. and it was 195 lbs so UPS wouldn't ship it back to you. I got the first one all packaged up and they picked it up.
The next day it was sitting on my front porch on it's top. I couldn't even get out of my door since the unit was placed in front of my door. So being 63 and having to try and move this 195 lbs package off my porch was another interesting undertaking. So had to go buy some 2x4's and build a ramp to get the package up and my truck. So there was another expense. The 2nd one was the same way, you sent a tag from UPS, they picked it up and brought it back the next day. 
I hope all your customers aren't treated this way or your company will go the way of your first phone a failure. If I can post this message on your website I surely will because this is totally an unacceptable way to do business in my opinion. 
I also very mad at all the run around I have been getting on getting the refund. Was told the first time the credit you gave me for the bent up sleeve was compensation for the work done on the unit and the full price would be credited back to me if I didn't want to exchange it but that was another fib I guess because it sure wasn't. 
I'm sure no one will read this unless I can post it on Amazon's website someplace or somewhere I can give you a rating on your business. 

Thanks for nothing, thanks for all the run around and thanks for all my added expense to get heat in my building. 

Tim
title: “You know this is the worst buying experience I have...”

content:
Even if you can put aside the horrible treatment of Amazon employees, even if you can overlook the fact that Amazon is killing brick and mortar (along with all those retail jobs), this company is still horrible. There customer service is a joke. Fraud runs rampant now. I'm a savvy shopper and still got scammed twice in the last few months. 

First ordered a Nintendo Switch was charged and received a tracking number that never moved. It took Amazon far too long to refund the obvious scam. Second time I got a fake 200 GB SanDisk micro SD card. It looked like a legit 200 GB card, but was just blank plastic on the backside and was actually only an 8 GB card. Again Amazon was slow to refund and amazingly didn't even close down the scam sellers account.

I then received an Amazon gift card as a gift from my aunt that had a zero balance on it when I tried to use it. Amazons response was basically too bad so sad. They said, "It appears someone other than the intended recipient used the gift card. We cannot offer a refund." Gee that's nice, and when I asked who used the card they said that info is private. They admit the card was fraudulently used, but then hide who did it and do no further investigation. No wonder scams run rampant on Amazon, their rules literally promote scammers.

That was the final straw, I cancelled a huge Christmas order I had placed as well as my Prime membership. The funny thing is Amazon actually isn't always the cheapest, they've just brainwashed us all into thinking it. 

I ended up becoming a Gamers Club Member at Best Buy and reordered all the Christmas stuff even cheaper than it was from Amazon and felt good supporting a brick and mortar store and the sales associates who depend on that job.

Amazon is a horrible company that is getting so big they believe they don't have to care about anyone. Stop supporting this company, or in the future we will all be forced to work for Amazon and buy from Amazon, as they will have fulfilled their evil plan and put all brick and mortar stores out of business.
title: “Evil as they come”

content: I believe Amazon is involved in fraud. They seem to have a glitch in their online ordering system that causes you to order items that you do not want. I was ordering two books, but had others in my shopping cart, I selected a quantity of 0 on the items that I did not want. The only step to proceed from that page was to place the order, and the items that I had select as 0 quantity where ordered. Immediately afterwards I cancelled the order! And received confirmation of the cancelation, but still the order was placed. So now even if I cancel my order I still have to pay shipping. A company as big as this would not make their website so user friendly with out it being an intentional way to make customers spend more $$ then the intend to. Seems like fraud to me.
title: “I believe Amazon is involved in fraud”

content:
Dont buy from Amazon seller Stores123.

I bought this as a Christmas present for my fiance who likes modern furniture. I received the item and upon unpacking it, it seemed as though it had already been unpacked. The box was tattered and the packing tape had been retaped. Once I opened the product, I inspected it and found the underside fabric was torn where there was a piece of the wood frame supporting the center. It was not a large tear but it was a tear never-the-less. I decided that it was likely a used product sent by mistake so I repacked it immediately. Given that Christmas was a few days away, I went to a local furniture shop and found something similar to buy in time for Christmas.

I bought the product because it was on Amazon so I felt comfortable. I do understand Amazon uses 3rd party sellers and the return policy for this seller seemed straight-forward: if the product is damaged, they buyer can return it for a full refund. The seller has been trying to get the 15% restocking fee from the beginning of my communication with them. I dont think I should have to pay $100+ to them because they sent me a used product by mistake. They are claiming that there is no tear on the bottom fabric but that is absolutely not true and I am surprised they would blatantly lie like that. They have even sent me photos they took upon return of the product and the tear is shown (again, it is not big, but it is there and it is something I would consider as damage and would buy off a classified bulletin board).

At this point, I have requested them to refund me 100% of what I paid and I have disputed the charge through my credit card issuing bank. Stores123 have not replied to me with any message indicating they will provide me a 100% refund. They have offered to send me the product back (which I clearly do not want) or to pay a 15% restocking fee. I really feel extorted here as they are in clear violation of their return policy.
title: “Dont buy from Amazon seller Stores123”

content:
I had purchased from them for the last 12 years and had no problem. However,  I recently bought an electronic item and needed it returned.  Amazon sided with the seller. The seller agreed to the return, e-mailed me that it received the item back and refused to refund money.  Amazon knew this, had Post Office Delivery proof, and only sent protected e-mails to the seller. When this didn't work, Amazon refused to help me. 

On my own I had to find out Sellers address and phone number and contact them. They claimed I wasn't in their system at all and never heard of the company that shipped it. I told them the 3 names the Corporation was registered as being under, the two addresses, and the Presidents' name.  I told them I would be contacting the State Attorney's Office for fraud, US mail order fraud, and credit card fraud, etc. They hung up on me. The next day  Amazon credited my charge. I will never use Amazon again. They still allow this company to sell on their site knowing they are frauds.
title: “I had purchased from them for the last 12 years and...”

title: “Great everytime!”

content:
Horrid customer service! I recently bought an iPod touch from Amazon (the actually site, not a reseller listed on the site) and recently got a phone call from them saying I now owe a collection agency $275 for the iPod (note, this call was from Amazon, NOT the agency).

After the first call this morning (November 3rd) I called Amazon back to ensure this wasn't a spoof of some sort (seeing as the number was 5 digits). After talking to Amazon the first time, I was told that the reason I owe money was that I did not have the funds needs to pay for the iPod when they tried to charge me yesterday (November 2nd). I was also told that they had contacted my bank-which, after a talk with my bank, they didn't do-to ensure I had the funds needed at the time of ordering (October 20). After the explantion of Amazon's poor charging times, I was told to contact the collection agency to talk to them.

So I did. I couldn't get in touch with them [the collection agency] so I called my bank for suggestions on my next step. I was told to call Amazon back, which I did. After having to explain to them [Amazon] what I was told earlier, I was contacted to a three way call with myself, the Amazon rep, and a rep from the collection agency. The agency was rather gruff with me, but I was rather pissed, and was trying to get a simple answer out of the Amazon rep who was still on the line: why did you send me an iPod without being paid(To me, this seems like a horrible business trait)? Instead of an answer to that, I was told that my account number (since I "paid" for the iPod directly from my bank account) must have been typed wrong. To which I asked why Amazon didn't tell me at the moment of this realization on their part.

All said and done, I will NEVER use Amazon again. I realize I am only one person not using a multi-national company, but due to this terrible way of dealing with not only their customers, but their money.
title: “Horrid customer service!”

content:
It's easy to get lured in by the cheap prices for new hard cover books. But I feel they have gone too far. I mean, you can buy anything from baby wipes to a tire iron. Why does it need to be so big?

And when I had a problem with a merchant who overcharged me (some sort of clerical error on THEIR part) over 8 times what I was quoted to pay it took me nearly 3 months to clear it up. There is no phone number to call and talk to a live human being and I had to send email after email to try to clear it up. It was ridiculous. 

But let's focus on their book review section for a moment: I really hated a book and gave it one star. The author harassed me using various aliases and, then worst of all, got Amazon.com to pull me one star review AND I was accused of hectoring this author. All because this one little crybaby (named Paul Cohn...look it up...I kid you not) complained. And what I found especially fascinating about this particular author is that besides writing total crap "novels" he attacked everyone who gave his book anything less than 5 stars and ALL of his 5 star reviews were from "people" who had never written another book review in their LIFE! I mean... it wasn't a best seller... it maybe sold 20 or 30 copies and it has about 10 5 star reviews that these reviewers have NEVER written another single book review. 

I mean, if that doesn't reek or sound of fish, I don't know what does. And Amazon comes down on me??? well, that's just crazy. I say skip Amazon.com and buy local (even though I do live in Seattle, so Amazon is local for me)...because there are so many other book stores who deserve your business. 

And don't even get me started on their secondary market. I recently purchased a book that was said to be in "like new" condition. When I got it the cover was torn, there was a red wine (I hope it was red wine) stain on it and worse of all!!! Some passages in the book were underlined in pen! So I complained 3 weeks ago and they said they would refund my money...but have they? ope. And I'll bet you anything it will take between 10-15 emails to get them to honor their money back guarantee. That was 3 weeks ago, and I have not received an email saying that my money was refunded.

I would say this is the ONLY time I would ever say: Set fire to Amazon! (because I associate that name with a particular rain forest that is in peril).

Plain and simple: they suck...long, hard and completely.
title: “It's easy to get lured in by the cheap prices for new...”

content: I have had a Amazon buying account for years now, mostly buying books and mp3's with relative satisfaction. I had always sold strictly on Ebay.com for 4 years now and have always been happy with my experience there. So last week I decided I would try selling on Amazon. I set up my seller account, listed 5 items for sale and figured that would be it. I'd check it every day to see if any of my items sold. The next day I checked it and to my surprise, Amazon stated that they had suspended my account because of policy violations. Upon further inspection I found out that they had suspended my account because they had linked my account to another suspended seller account. I thought this must be a mistake as I don't have nor have I ever had another amazon account. Nor does anyone living in my household, ie my girlfriend. After emailing amazon and explaining this I received a form generated email back from them stating that while they could not share any info on how they relate accounts or what account I am supposedly related to they had significant proof that I was linked to another account. After many emails I finally called there customer service and was told in exact words, there was nothing they could do to help me. I asked if there was a superior I could talk to or anyone who could help me and was told no, that department does not respond by phone. At this point I was getting very frustrated, and after a few more emails back and forth, with every single amazon response being another form generated email, I finally contacted the better business bureau. Well, alot of good that did. Amazon gave them the same bulls&*t response they gave me. So I asked, if someone is using my name, bank account etc, shouldn't they tell me what this so called account is I am linked to so I can put a stop to. Well, Amazon does not give any info on how they link accounts, I'm just supposed to take there word for it that I am linked to another account. Finally I contacted amazon to close any and all accounts related to my name and after probably 10 emails and 4 or 5 more phone calls, all just to get my damn account closed, because I WILL NEVER, EVER , EVER shop their crap website again, I finally managed to get my account closed for good. I don't know who the hell amazon thinks they are but this is one website I will never be visiting again. I have sold on Ebay for 4 years now and have a 99.7 percent rating on there, and have never encountered anything like this at all. If I have to call Ebay, I am always able to talk to a live person who usually can solve my problem in a matter of minutes. Amazon has poor customer service at best. AT BEST! I am not the only one with complaints like these either, google AMAZON SUCKS and look at all the pages. Many, many sellers with similar stories and alot of even worse horror stories about sellers having their money held for months on end, their accounts closed for no reason. Someone needs to file a class action lawsuit against these clowns and end their reign of terror.
title: “I have had a Amazon buying account for years now, mostly...”

content:
Amazon is not the first website that I would order an item from. Amazon has a tendency to deliver packages days after it was scheduled for delivery .Sometimes they don't even ship your package until the day that it was supposed to be delivered to you. If it's an important item that you drastically need in a hurry I suggest shopping somewhere else. They are sometimes very unreliable, their customer service can use some improvement, and their delivery times are usually unpredictable to say the least. 

I ordered lights to decorate my dorm room off of amazon and I never received my order from them. When I first ordered it they told me that it would come within 4 to 5 business days: however, that was not the case. My lights did not ship until the 4th day of me waiting for them. I waited a couple days to see if my package would come. After about three days of not receiving my "shipped" package I decided that it was time to take matters into my own hands. I first called the delivery company that was supposed to drop off my package and they said that they never got a package for my address or name. I then decided to email amazon and they replied back saying that my item was shipped to the postal service that would be delivering it. Although, they said that my items were shipped I still did not receive them days later so I decided to call the company to and find out why. 
The first time I gave them a call I was on hold for at least 30 minutes waiting to talk to a representative. After being on hold for a significant amount of time, I was told that there were no available representatives to talk to at that time and that I should call the next day. The next day when I called I was on hold for a while but I finally got to talk to someone about my order. I was told that my order had been sent back because of an unknown error. I never got an email or notification saying that the order that I have been waiting on for weeks was sent back. When I asked why my order got sent back the representative told me that she was not sure why but sometimes it just happens. When I asked for my money she told me that I had to email amazon or go to the website and click on "about refunds" and ask back for my money there. So I emailed amazon and asked them for a refund due to the fact that my package got canceled but I never got my money back. The next day they emailed me and said they would refund me my money back within 24 hours of my initial email. I waited for the money but it never went back into my account so I emailed them again and this time they didn't respond until days later saying that, once again, they would send my money back to me.
 After not receiving my money a second time I just decided not to worry about it and just decided to be cautious of where and what I buy online. Next time I know not to rely on Amazon so much for my online shopping. Next time I know to be cautious and what sites I shop on. If you do decide to shop on Amazon just be mindful of what you get and who the seller is that you are getting the product from.
title: “Not the best experience.”

I would not support a company like that, you may save money now but your loosing your economy to others and robots.

content: Amazon used to be this amazing company from a customer standpoint, but now that it has shut down most of its competition and continues to grow, the company is starting to tank. Prime is no longer Prime as you're paying more for it and receiving less. Two day shipping is a lie, it's more like 4 or 5 day or whenever they feel like it shipping. Returns are more difficult to make and their product pricing is steadily increasing. The media and entertainment portion is a joke. This includes both the tv and music portion. I have increasingly found better products and prices fro other companies and I am seriously considering cancelling my Prime membership. content: All of a sudden books written in 1980 are now priced at $20 by Amazon. The price of books has risen through Amazon by almost 50% in some cases. It turns out that Amazon is trying to get people to buy through their Kindle e-books by pricing hard copy too high for the value (clever marking but customer negative and expensive). Nasty policy.  Returns have become more difficult, much more.  Some manager ahs decided that a way to raise profits for unfortunate buyers is too exclude the Buyer and limit returns.  If you have, by some magic ghost like decision Maker as Amazon have returned too many item, in their minds, then you are notified that you cannot buy anymore. Many people have protested, many reinstated.  The real issue is that Amazon allows any hack two-bit outfit to sell on Amazon. So people receive bad products, out-of-spec products, damaged products, etc. more often then in the past. Returns have escalated due to Amazons anyone can sell policy. It is definitely not the Purchaser but the Seller who need to be excluded. Amazon claims to review Sellers for performance which is very limited.  When greed dominates it is a real 'fire'.  The policy that has been established is profit above service, quality, product performance, product as suppose to be.
title: “Books expensive and returns diffiult (NOW)”

content:
For years I've been a regular Amazon.com Prime customer, and had once found their offerings and customer service both to be (past tense) terrific.  During these past 6 months however I've observed some changes in the customer experience of this "customer centric company"; several of my orders now arrive minus total quantities, fragile items are not packed well at all or arrive completely damaged, and some missing orders only arrive after a follow up email is sent to Amazon.com Founder, Chairman, and CEO Mr. Jeff Bezos.  In one recent month, 10 of my orders have arrived in an abysmal state; upon a review of each parcel it was not the fault of the shipping company.  
In the interim, Amazon Prime Movies that were once available for no fee to paying Amazon Prime members are now available for additional fees.  
All the while, Amazon.com has raised its annual Amazon Prime Fee to $119.:
"Amazon is justifying Primes 20 percent price hike, to $119 a year, by saying it is more a valuable service than when the fee last rose four years ago"
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/business/wp/2018/04/27/how-to-get-around-amazon-primes-new-119-fee/?noredirect=on&utm_term=.ca2d4aa7a96

Amazon.com, customer centric or ego centric?

content:
I have bought a few dozen items and have some issues with their practices. 
One: using free shipping with minimum purchase amount, they always sit on the order from 5 to 7 business days.These are in stock items and status reads preparing for shipment.I have seen credible reports detailing how efficient they and how they slave drive their order pickers. Sellers on ebay virtually always ship out next day. So why a week stalling my orders, EVERY time? I can only conclude its to force customers using free shipping to join amazon prime. 
So I did. 
Or at least wanted to. 
I check the box for free 30 day membership and placed an order using my debit card.
A couple of hours later I get an email and it says my order cant be shipped because my debit card turned down the $100 prime membership fee. Huh? 
The terms and conditions of prime free trial clearly state that amazon charges you the $100 at the END of the 30 day trial. And thats if you want the year of prime. Guess they lied. I ordered  the same item from ebay. No problems.
I guess they figure most people will take prime anyway after the trial and not notice they were billed a month earlier or figure fighting them for a refund if they dont is futile. 
Dishonest company.
title: “Shady but could be worse”

content: I feel compelled to update my review in light of Amazon's rotten service as of the past six months or so.  Most of my supposed 2-day delivery orders never make it in two days, if I receive them at all (which then necessitates phone calls on my end to Amazon).  The delivery companies have even posted pictures of other people's houses and claim that our house is where they delivered our packages.  I've also received wrong merchandise that Amazon wanted ME to pay for to return!  The delivery services they use are THE WORST!!  Most of the time, our packages are either shoved into our mailbox or set beside it AT THE CURB, some of them getting soaked by the rain (I'm sorry that we live on a private drive, but for $99 per year for Prime, I expect better service).  But the worst situation was recently when, on Amazon's own website in the My Orders section, it was stated that a Prime Pantry order of mine (my first order with PP, by the way) had been delivered 8 DAYS BEFORE WE ACTUALLY RECEIVED IT!!  Not to mention that it had been placed, again, next to our mailbox, IN THE POURING RAIN!  A neighbor called and told us that she saw it.  The products inside that were in cardboard boxes were damp, but luckily nothing was ruined.  The first person with whom I spoke at Amazon had to transfer me to another department (after dealing with ANOTHER order of mine that had been claimed on Amazon was delivered, as well, but was not).  The second woman was VERY nice and said that Amazon is aware of all of the delivery problems and is working on it.  I did end-up getting the choice of a refund or another box of them same items delivered for free, as well as have my $7.99 shipping cost returned (yeah, that even made it worse - the fact that I had PAID almost $8 to have THIS kind of service >:-(  ).  It's interesting how the free box of items showed-up the next day on my doorstep :-/ .  Anymore, I try to find what I need on ANY other website and only go to Amazon for what I can't get anywhere else.  I really don't know how much longer we'll keep our Prime subscription.  Some other company needs to throw their hat in the ring and knock Amazon off its pedestal!
title: “What a Difference a Year Makes :-( ...”

content:
I really used to like Amazon, but a few recent experiences are making me reconsider my Prime membership, or doing much business with them at all. First, I had ordered some items for Christmas~ I ordered on December 18th, and they were due on the 20th. Then I get an e-mail saying the package would be delayed, and they were due on the 22nd. Christmas Eve morning, I contact them by chat and tell them I am hosting a holiday party in a few hours and still don't have the package. They again tell me that it is "delayed", that it is "lost in transit" but they assure that I will get the package by the end of the day (I did not), and they will refund the amount. I ask if I will still get the items if I am refunded, and that representative says that I will. Christmas morning, I contact them again and they say the package was lost, and that I need to reorder the items, but that negates the refund I was credited. I ask what they are going to do about the fact that my original package was never received, and the Christmas items we were waiting for will be arriving well after Christmas. They tell me that they will give me a credit of $5 to use towards my next order (then they say they will make it a $15 credit). However, we just recently placed an order, and I'm pretty sure they did not apply any credit to it.

The second issue is that they charged our daughter's student card (which she had registered under our account so she could get things she needs for school) for our Hulu subscription. I asked why her card was suddenly charged when it has always been charged to the same card. They tried to say that there was not sufficient funds on our card, so that is when they charged hers. I checked our account and there were enough funds in our account when they charged her card. I told them that they should have given us notice if there were insufficient funds instead of going ahead and using her card, and that they should refund the amount to her, which they said they were going to do. But today they send an e-mail saying they are not able to refund the amount to her card! I told them that is not acceptable, so we shall see what happens after this.

 I definitely notice a decline in their customer service from previous years. It used to be if there were any issues (which were rare), they were resolved quickly and with limited contact. Now I've had two negative experiences in less than a month of each other, I got bounced around between at least 5 different representatives last time, and the representatives try to placate you while telling you they cannot really help you (and it is not easy to understand what they are saying, the messages are in broken English). I have seen several people on other review sites saying that they have been told that 2- Day Shipping no longer applies (even though that is what they advertise and you pay for)....if that is the case, what is the point of having a Prime membership?
title: “Things are changing, and not in a good way...”

content: I have attempted to order stuff three times from Amazon.  Bad news every time.  First time it took several months to arrive.  When I got it, I realized why.  It had been sent by surface mail from Finland (to me in Canada).  Second time I ordered from Amazon it arrived two weeks after the promised date.  But by the time it arrived I had already been refunded after my complaint.  The third time I attempted to order from them was last week: When I entered my order for an item costing $20 their system told me if I ordered at least $35 of stuff I would get free shipping.  So I changed my order to double the amount of the identical product from the same supplier.  When I did that they then said I had to order over $50 to get free shipping, and when I increased my order, again, this time to $53, at the check out they added $20 more to cover shipping.  I cancelled the order, and when I complained they tried to shift the blame to the shipper of the goods, when it had been THEIR ordering process that had been making the promises of free shipping.  In two words:  silly deceit.  I doubt I will waste any more time trying to order stuff from Amazon in the future.
