content:
I don't even know where to start with this review. I think anyone who's paying attention would see there are cheaper and easier places to shop, but clearly people simply shop for convenience these days. Not to mention they're building a complete Monopoly and yet paying zero federal taxes. In my opinion Amazon is everything that's wrong with our culture. We don't typically shop there anyway but were recently gifted an item from a prime member.  This experience has been a catastrophe from start to finish:

- First, the price jumped $9 from the time I found the item to the time they were ordered, which was about 24 hours.
- item arrived and sizing was completely off.
- This was a gift, yet I was told exchanges are not allowed unless the item is defective and you're exchanging for the EXACT same size, color, etc. So they would send a return label then send a gift card once the item was received.
- item shipped back quickly and the card was sent to my email...for the cheaper price of the item, NOT the price that was paid for it.
- I emailed customer service, who said "well, send us the original order number and we'll look into it." (Obviously I'd provided the original number when I requested the return. But, fine, I'll play their games. At this point I've already decided I won't be doing business with them ever again. I'm just trying to get through it to get my son his birthday gift!!)
- I did a customer service chat, and was told sure they'd send the remaining balance, although they had actually charged us (the gift recipient) for return shipping and subtracted it from the value of the gift!! Unbelievable.
- We just realized they sent the shipping fee to the original sender, so my son is still short $9 on the value of his gift. The prime member who sent the gift suggested we just send her the gift card number and she'll reorder the correct size. This is far too many hoops to jump through to send or receive a simple gift. We will not be doing business with them again.
title: “They've permanently lost my business”

content: Amazon used to be great, and was my go to site for ordering anything online. However in the last few times I ordered from them, my packages were delivered by "flex drivers." I live in a building with locked doors to the lobby that require a key to get in. In the past the mail people would just put my package in the mailbox or leave it by the door for me. But these flex drivers don't have keys and would ring my bell over and over and over and over. When I got downstairs some Joe Schmo off the street is holding my package, rudely shoving it at me and running away. The first time it happened I thought my package was sent to a neighbor across the street by mistake and he was pissed about it. He acted like I really inconvenienced him and pissed him off. But after 3 more incidents I did some research and realized that these random people are handling my packages, and every single one of them has been completely RUDE. Maybe it's just the area I live in, but not one of them has been polite and I don't appreciate being disturbed. I don't want strangers off the street handling my stuff and ringing my doorbell over and over again. I live on the 3rd floor, have a small child and work from home. It's not convenient or an enjoyable experience to order from Amazon anymore, which is a shame. I used to love Amazon prime but I will never resubscribe to it until they get rid of these flex drivers and only let professionals handle packages. And I haven't missed them at all. I can get the same stuff from ebay, often cheaper with free shipping without the hassle or subscription fee. Prime TV isn't worth it either. There's only a few shows and movies you can watch and they charge you for the good stuff. You have access to about 10 crappy kindle books that no one wants to read. Not worth the $99 bucks IMO.
title: “Flex drivers ruined it”

content:
Amazon used to be my first choice when making a purchase online. Great selection, good prices and fast shipping. But that's all changing. Over the past year or so i have noticed that Prime shipping is no longer 2 days but mostly 3-4 plus packing is taking 1-4 days so a 2 day Prime shipment can turn into 7 days or more. The actual packing has become very bad, a recent delivery of books have been thrown in with tools or other items without any protection, resulting in a book that looks decidedly second hand before they have even been used. I never used to have to return items but this year about 15% of all my orders have arrived damaged. Prices used to be the best but with a little Google search I'm find better deals on other sites and now that Amazon has decided to start charging tax on all sales, other sites are looking so much more appealing.
As other reviewers have stated Amazon is getting too big and losing sight of its roots.
title: “Been purchasing from Amazon since 1995 and it's going downhill fast !!”

content: Amazon has decent prices for Prime members and if you can't locate something specific in your town, Amazon is easy. Unfortunately, too many fakes have taken over. I ended up with a knockoff Kylie lip gloss that caused a rash, knockoff vitamins and a supplement I bought there gave me an allergic reaction. Turned out it was sawdust mixed with something called "white cut." (I know a lab tech in FL, sent her a pill to test for me.) There are more Chinese knockoffs on there than not for everything including top name brand stuff. I ended up with a shampoo "sold by" a regular shelf brand here but ended up with a really weird knockoff -packaging and all. Amazon has started putting all products of the same labeling into one big bin. If you buy Olay face cream, you may end up with one by Olay or one of the infamous knockoffs -regardless of who you bought it from and what you paid. It's called "big boxing." Shop with caution.
title: “Too many fakes have taken over...including vitamins.”

content:
My last review of Amazon was favorable.  However, Amazon's Customer Service, which was once the best in the industry, is now among the worst in the industry.
Representatives are most often in foreign countries, extremely difficult to understand, and argumentative.
Amazon's procedure of telephoning you in response to your Email request is no more.  Contacting Amazon Customer Service is a maze of screens that provide neither Email or telephone number direction.  (Amazon Customer Service can be reached toll free at: 1-866-216-1072, but do not anticipate cooperation or assistance.)  
Allowing that one of their primary competitors now offers two day free shipping on many orders, in addition to free to store shipping, Amazon's dramatic reduction in customer service is not well timed.
Amazon needs to use their drones to examine their customer service.
title: “Customer Service Now An Oxymoron”

I mean, the man is #1 richest in the world, unless one has a vested interest in displacing the Waltons as the #1 family in the world to hold the Walmart corporations and billions of USD, one should diligently practice the science of skinflintery. I heavily regret any dealings with anyone selling items on this website, and unless anonymous individuals known as 'Michael Deering' want to face me on the defamation lawsuit stand or queue up for a restraining order they should end Amazon's web service support. The warehouses in Amazon power 10,000 lb packing and shipping machines to fill and send the customer packages, to avoid liability and a potential lawsuit, so no one would be any the wiser if an individual's body were placed in a restraining device and thrown violently down the conveyor belt and buried offsite or cremated. Drones flying the skies carry 3,000 lbs. of Amazon merchandise across the skies and it is only a matter of time before they pick someone off or assert non-platonic connections of anyone that they perform surveillance on. Save yourselves and practice the narrowest skinflintery possible, hide your loved ones and stay off the Internet.

content:
I've been shopping on Amazon almost since their inception back in 1994.  My overall experience for the past 20-years has been great.  I've had a seller and a buyer account.  I've purchased hard to find items at very competitive prices.  Up until the past year I've had absolutely no issues.

Notably, over the past two-years Jeff Bezos has contracted outside of the USA (Amazon was a Seattle based company) and invested literally BILLIONS of dollars in India.  Wow!

Not only do I disagree with that (US companies should keep jobs in the US, this is totally selling out), but there's a reason labor is cheaper in India - it's of a lower quality.

This is my story.  I had signed up for the free 6-month Amazon Prime Student membership.  For some reason I forgot to cancel it after the 6-month trial and the $49 membership fee was deducted from my account (no pre-warning this was about to happen).  As I didn't want Prime membership I contacted Amazon and cancelled the Prime membership.  Two weeks later the same thing happened - another $49 deducted from my bank account for Prime membership.  Why?  I have no idea.  I didn't sign up for Prime again.  Not only could this have sent my bank account overdrawn but it was an unauthorized withdrawal of funds from my bank account.  Wow!  That's usually referred to as 'theft'.

I decided to close my Amazon account completely as I did not want to risk this happening again.  Now, if you ever want to close your Amazon account you will see that there are no less than 7-steps, plus an email verification process, and then a 24-hour wait with no confirmation email that your account has actually been closed.  The process is so convoluted it is literally designed to make closing your account extremely difficult.  What a low-ball tactic to keep you.  During the process I went online and 'chatted' with customer support.  The customer support person I spoke to (Guarab) had a very poor command of the English language and did not offer anything helpful at all.  Why would he?  He's on the other side of the planet and English is not his first language.

I did some research and sure enough (search it up yourself - I just used Wikipedia) between 2014 and 2016 Amazon invested over $5 BILLION DOLLARS in India!!!!  

Wow!!!  So, Jeff Bezos apparently isn't rich enough (despite his net worth of over $72 BILLION DOLLARS!!!) that he has to take jobs to India instead of investing here in America where he lives and where Amazon was birthed.  I despise companies that do that.  They're sell outs.  

I would have given Amazon a one star review but I'm actually trying to be fair.  They served me well for 20-years.  It's only been the past year that they've really let me down and, in my opinion, sold out.  

Ironically, Jeff Bezos money making strategy of investing in India (let's be honest - it's not because India is a beautiful country, it's exclusively because of the cheap labor force) has backfired on him because now he's lost my custom for life!  The few dimes he hoped to save by hiring cheap (and ineffective) labor from India has actually cost him his customer base (in my case at least).

Greed is a terrible thing Jeff.  You can't take any of it with you.  Thanks for selling out.
title: “Too bad they chose to contract out to India instead of the USA”

content: Amazon used to be one of my favorite places to go online even though the Canadian Amazon is not the US Amazon and it doesn't have the same products nor the same prices but that was ok for the most part and then they changed.   They've gone the route of trying to be another Ebay with 3rd party sellers who try to sell at 2, 3 and more times the average retail prices.  The schemers who go there are not reputable and may not even have the items they're trying to sell but that doesn't appear to bother Amazon.  I have ordered some products from Amazon, never received a tracking number at least none that you could use.  If you shop at Amazon, I would strongly recommend you avoid Amazon Market Place or suffer whatever burns comes with it.   I really don't know what Amazon management was thinking but they have degraded their online shopping to a level I'd prefer to avoid.  BestBuy, Staples and many others don't have nor need a Market Place with 3rd party sellers but then you don't need an RMA number to return anything either.   Two stars Amazon and falling fast.

content: At the beginning this site was one of the best ecommerce. Good prices, good service and wonderful customer service. But in the last couple of year it has being awful. Schools constantly change text books and don't let you know what they are using with much time.  After I finished my course (a month later) I hadn't received my text book and I had to cancel my transaction with my credit card.  I couldn't easily find the customer service number in the page.  As I was student from an accredited university I registered for the Student Prime account, but they logged me in a trial version of Prime that expired after 3 months.  When I called them they said they couldn't correct the classification of my membership until a year later so I couldn't use the benefit of being student as they advertise. Be careful with this site.  Good luck.

content:
I've been using Amazon for years as both a buyer and a seller. Over the last couple of years their shipping has gotten worst and worse and so has their customer service. 

The last few items I've ordered from Amazon (not from 3rd party sellers) have been terribly packaged and arrived defective. Amazon does take returns, but shipping it back is a huge hassle and nobody ever bothers to apologize for wasting my time when they send me a broken item. There is nobody held responsible and there's no way to contact them directly if I want to ask for them to package a delicate item more appropriately.

On top of the broken items and extra slow shipping, I've recently been locked out of my account because of security issues that they will not clarify. I've called their customer service- and they've been incredibly useless, namely because they're outsourced oversea. Nobody will tell me why I can't get into my account. They tell me they don't know and another department will handle it. I ask to speak to that department and they say they will contact me. It's been days and I've heard nothing. If I didn't have a gift card balance, I'd likely just forget about my account and be done with them.

Amazon is a soulless corporation that is responsible for the loss of countless jobs. Saving two or three dollars just isn't worth dealing with them. Support somebody that has a face and cares about their customers instead.
title: “They're Going Downhill Fast”

content: Amazon is ridiculous!  If you just want to buy things every now and then, Amazon is fine, but if you would like to sell ANYTHING AT ALL this is NOT THE PLACE FOR YOU!  If you are a seller, Amazon will use and abuse you time and time again.  Amazon may close your account for absolutely no reason at all! The worst thing is that you will never be able to get anyone to help you get your selling privileges back and they don't care one bit.  Lastly, if you don't ship items the way that they prefer (signature confirmation -of course Amazon never explained this to me in time, they waited until something bad happened in order to inform me), you will surely pay for it in the fact that none of your transactions will be covered AT ALL.  I sold an item in AUGUST of 2015 and in FEBRUARY of 2016, they decided to claim they never received it (for those doing the math at home, that's SEVEN MONTHS AGO) and Amazon sided with them!  I had all the proof I needed, but Amazon didn't care; they said it was insufficient and even though it was that long ago, it made no difference.  Now I'm out $600 AND Amazon closed my account!
title: “Good for Buyers.... HORRIBLE FOR SELLERS!”

So that December I bought christmas from Amazon then I bought everyone's birthdays and through the she year of 2015 I prob spent more than a thousand dollars at amazon this year in 2016 I even started buying some groceries it was then that I thought man this is to good to be true cheap prices fast delivery soooo I dug into my account and found that my husband's card had been charged $104 for prime membership I assume that was our 2nd $104 payment I just missed it last January sooo I got nervous I'm 27 but I swear my blood pressure raised I got hot and red and sweaty so first thing the next morning I called 16 days after the charge appeared on the bank statement and to my surprise the refunded the entire $104 or they said they did I haven't checked at the bank and that was only about 4 or 5 days ago so I thought amazon isn't that bad after all my complaint there was my goodness send an email reminder or something that alerts customers they are about to be charged anyway so my prime membership is canceled I no longer have free 2 day shipping I just use free shipping and it sucks I placed an order for a knife set as a gift and it's been 4 days  just processing it hasn't even shipped yet 4 days to process is a very long time in my opinion I think im done with amazon... content: Remember when Amazon gave free shipping at any $25 orders?  You've probably noticed that's no longer possible, unless you sign up for Prime.  Prime in itself is probably a decent offering; however, not everybody needs or wants it, and therefore you get dinged in shipping costs.  (shame on you!)  That aside (as I could go on for a while), the main complaint here are sellers using Amazon to sell their goods, let's say used books.  These sellers blame Amazon for not allowing them to combine shipping.  Is that true Amazon?  Where is your voice in all of this?  Shipping is $3.99 flat rate for books.  Anyone who's ever used USPS Media rates knows that you can ship printed material pretty inexpensively--less than $3.99.  If this is true that Amazon won't 'ALLOW' combined shipping, then Amazon is looking for trouble in reduced sales.  Just talking locally here with many people who used to use Amazon exclusively, I can tell you they have found other avenues.  Also, these sellers put themselves on Amazon.com under multiple different names and then combine shipping for themselves, but never pass on those savings to you, the buyer.  Where is Amazon's voice in all of this deceit?  Do you like having them try to slip this by you?  I think more and more people are going to revert back to buying locally, because the entire online marketing is becoming more dishonest and more of a scam.  Keep your eyes open buyers!
title: “Seriously going downhill”

content:
Amazon is a great financial success. I'm an investor and customer - but their customer service is insulting and incompetent. While, they generally provide a good selling service experience on simple common items, where they fail utterly is trying to understand what would make their customers - better customers on something that requires accurate dimensions, weights, and colors:

1. There is no contact point on the Amazon site for communication regarding Amazon customer service - just third party sellers.
2. Amazon does a miserable job at policing its sellers and their own ads regarding standardizing product descriptions and making sure they are correct. About 80% of Amazon product ads are incorrect or incomplete regarding critical specifications of the their products.

I would have much rather dealt with Amazon directly, but again they have no Amazon service feed back or way of reaching customer service directly on their web site. Even though Amazon is clearly successful, as an investor and a customer - I know they could be far more successful if they provided a method and listened to their customers.

content:
When you search for an item, you can waste hours finding what you want, because there is no policing of the rules.  You can get literally thousands of hits that have nothing to do with the keywords you entered.  In order to search by price, you must select one of Amazon's often pointlessly similar categories.  Then, often, you will get literally thousands of entries that are identical.  For many items, you will get thousands of entries that have price $0.01, accompanied by shipping costs of, for example, $10.00.  This makes searching by price futile.  If you want to skip over these thousands of rule violators, you can't do it because Amazon only lets you skip ahead 2 pages.  (Not only that, but they won't let you see more than 25 items per page.)  They ought to let you enter the number of the page you want to visit next.
I have complained to Amazon numerous times about this, pointing out that the experience at their competitor Ebay, for example, is much better.  I have threatened to file criminal complaints against them for being a nuisance.  They don't care.  The next step would be to be to get millions of Amazon visitors to file complaints with the Federal Trade Commission and state attorneys general, requesting that Amazon be declared a public nuisance and a public health nuisance, and requiring Amazon to meet reasonable and customary standards before transacting any further business.
title: “Software outdated, uncompetitive, doesn't allow searching by price, etc.”

content:
The one main problem I have with Amazon is their "fixed" reviews.  90% of the time when I write a 1 star review about any of their products, they REFUSE to publish it until I say something nice.  They protect their SELLERS not their BUYERS, and this will eventually come back and bite them in the rear. 
They appear to be in the market to control the entire online experience which is good and bad.  When their investors were paying for the services (their stocks skyrocketed even though they rarely showed profits), they could afford to do this.  But now that investors are starting to demand some sort of steady profitability and some return on their investments other than inflated stocks, Amazon looks like they are starting to worry and this is why they tend to manipulate buyer reviews. 
If you don't believe this, try it yourself.  Buy what you would consider a poor product and write a bad review.  Fortunately, at this point you will get a refund from Amazon, but your review will most likely be squashed.
title: “Most prominent on line seller but forgetting their customers”

I'm a Prime member, and I order almost everything from Amazon, so the money I save on shipping outweighs the cost of prime. However, I've become VERY DISGUSTED WITH PRIME VIDEO LATELY!! So all 3 movies I watched about 2/3 of the way through, fully believing I could watch the ending the next day. Oh no! 2 of the videos were NO LONGER INCLUDED ON PRIME THE VERY NEXT DAY!! The 3rd video was UNAVAILABLE! Hey, Amazon, that's not RIGHT TO DO! These were all either really old movies from the '90's or kind of jerky movies that the Sci-Fy channel used to show. That's another thing about Prime Videos-no current or recently current movies. That doesn't bother me, but when they are starting to shut off my access to the ends of movies, THAT ISNT RIGHT!

As for Amazon as a whole, I use it to buy almost everything.  I recommend that you always look to make sure each purchase is "Fulfilled by Amazon" before you buy it. I made a couple purchases that weren't all that great, and Amazon made sure I got a refund. Quickly, too. There are many sponsored items now, and most sellers are ethical and decent. But once in a while, you get a bad product, and if it's fulfilled by Amazon, Amazon stands behind it. (Except maybe now, for Prime Videos).

content:
Amazon is really broken down into two categories: 

1) customer
2) entrepreneur 

As a customer, I've found good deals but recently I was what one could say as "screwed over."

I ordered a book on July 22 which was supposed to be delivered by Sep 5. 
The book never showed up and I had to wait until October 2 to get it! 

As an Entrepreneur, I have a webstore on Amazon which has proved to be a nightmare. 
Firstly, inventory between .CA and .US is considered separate.
So in order for your products to climb the page rankings, although you have listings that pertain to both Canada and USA, only sales from each country will help you climb your rank-individually. This makes it extremely competitive. 

Also, setting up the page was very difficult. There was no customer service. 
The account manager simply told me to watch a "tutorial."
What is he/she getting paid for? 

It turned out that all my inventory got sent to Amazon's warehouse where they ended up losing the inventory, and once found, refused to store it for Amazon fulfillment, because our product bottles where "oversized,"-something they did not worn use about beforehand! 

The point is, as customer buying products Amazon is decent, but as someone trying to sell products (business seller's account), make sure you do your homework in advance and DO NOT rely on your account manager to help you out!
title: “Amazon is really broken down into two categories:”

content:
(Fifth update.) I've been purchasing from Amazon fairly heavily for years, not because I think it's the best source for merchandise (although it often is) but because its gift cards are the reward of choice for my participation answering queries for helpowl.com [which I've also reviewed for SiteJabber].

Pluses:

1. Price. Prices are generally excellent, and some purchases are tax-free. Many items are "eligible for free shipping," meaning that Amazon will not charge for shipping such items if their total price in one order is $25 or more. 

2. Return policy. Return policies are easy and quite generous, and with items shipped by Amazon the company pays for return shipping, or may even waive the need to return the item at all.

3. Promptness. Shipping is always prompt, even when free.

Minuses:

1. Support. I've now downgraded my star rating because of the increasingly terrible customer service. The good news is that phone support is usually, perhaps always, available. The bad news is the quality of that support:
(a) Thick accents by agents apparently based in other countries--even supervisors--make their advice largely unintelligible.
(b) Even when one can understand them, too many of the support personnel seem entirely clueless, taking the customer's time to no good end. Escalating to a supervisor sometimes works but often does not; and written support, usually provided as boilerplate, is usually still worse.
(c) Inquiries to Amazon's sellers must almost always be made via Amazon's online form; and, incredibly, Amazon cannot track such inquiries or follow up unless the purchase has already been made.

2. Product descriptions. These are wrong much too often. 

3. Product search. The variety of products available is overwhelming, and Amazon's product search engine is awful. For example, a search for a "queen-size single fitted sheet" yielded many hundreds of results (as I recall, about 1,400!), pointing to sheets of various sizes, nearly all sheets sets. Of all those results I found only 1 that matched my search criteria. One suspects that Amazon deliberately fudges search results to offer more choices, with the goal of increasing sales.

4. Merchant reviews. As of last check Amazon allows reviewers without significant limitation to withdraw their reviews. This policy encourages merchants -- many of whom depend on Amazon for patronage -- to go after reviewers whose reviews are not favorable in order to buy them off. This has happened to me.

The consequence of these minuses is that you could easily spend hours trying to meet your need, which may in the end be unfulfilled or, even worse, fulfilled badly.
title: “(Fifth update.) I've been purchasing from Amazon fairly...”

content: I purchased an item 2 weeks ago, 9 days later the price goes down so I contacted them to request an adjustment, they refused. The only recourse I had was to unwrap the Christmas presents, repackage them and return them for a refund. Then I could repurchase the exact items at the lower price, less the shipping cost of returning them of course. They would also take 2-3 weeks to process the refund, tying up my $640 during the Christmas season. I should have investigated before I purchased, nowhere on their site do they mention price guarantees, so I guess it is Caveat Emptor on me, but still a very frustrating situation.
title: “I purchased an item 2 weeks ago, 9 days later the price...”

content:
I've owned my Kindle fire for 4 years and use almost all of it's capabilities ..... including playing games ... most at level of 1000 or more.  Somehow my Kindle got reset to factory level and I lost EVERYTHING .... customer service said to re-register the Kindle, requiring total setup ..... security, settings,  etc.  I'm still finding things to update.  The games are gone ..... Amazon suggests I contact the game developers to get game data back.  They have no idea how the Kindle got unregistered .... they don't have the capability to find out.  BUT they did offer to compensate me for my inconvenience for hours of troubleshooting over the phone .... they offered to credit my account $10, which I declined.

The net is that Amazon technical support is purely clerical ..... they have a script for  
getting a customer running ..... at ground zero and that's all!!!!  And they have no way for a customer to do their own backups .....  And they suggested  I  caused the problem ... even though it would have taken 4 steps for me to reset ..... and I would have ignored several warnings that data would be destroyed ..... I only signed on (no password problems) .... and was met with an empty system.  Usually talking to a supervisor brings a new perspective .... but not with technical support ..... the answers were the same script .... clearly they have no  technical skills ..... they did not even opening a problem.  Only many, many apologies and a generous $10 compensation offer.  I am left feeling it could happen again .... I wish I had chosen another brand device.
title: “Amazon Kindle Technical Problem Skills Nonexistent”

content: AMAZON suck! they have nothing but iffy vendors that wants to sell you used items at MSRP!!
title: “AMAZON suck!”

content: i know it's the largest and entire ecommerce world looks up to amazon, but I personally don't like when finding a product is like a quest

content: Amazon screwed me over on a refund, after wasting several hours of my time.  The doublespeak & dishonesty was so incredible it was almost surreal.  The vendor actually refunded the money to Amazon, but Amazon never passed it on to me.  Despicable.  I know it's cheap and convenient (like Wal-Mart) but -  they are parasitic.  Get your stuff directly from the vendor!
title: “Amazon screwed me over on a refund, after wasting several...”

content: Amazon used to be my go-to place to save money and avoid going into shops (and pay for their rent!), but now there are so many different sellers and prices that you can no longer trust that you are getting a good deal. The same item can be priced *very* differently depending on the seller. Some prices are also absolutely ludicrous. For instance, I saw that someone was trying to sell the academic book that I authored for $1k !! It costs $100 directly from the publisher?! Shocking, to say the least. So although they have fantastic delivery and customer services, you constantly need to research whatever you wish to buy to make sure that you are not getting fooled. It's very tiring and time-consuming. There is absolutely no price regulation - you alone decide what you are willing to pay to get something delivered and/or rare. So prices don't match quality; rather, they reflect availability and the sheer greed of sellers. And they are killing our high street shops...
title: “It's changed”

content: It's fairly easy to navigate, but more and more I'm finding that there are better prices elsewhere. With the influx of private sellers, it's becoming more like ebay, where prices are all over the place and it's easy to overpay.
title: “It's OK”

title: “The service is really essential for those battling with a cheating spouse”

content:
Their mobile website is almost impossible to use and their desktop site is not a whole lot better.  Their customer service doesn't know what its own policies are and finding product information is almost impossible as customers who have no ability and/or interest in providing coherent input post on Amazon's "customer reviews" section of a product page and to make it more cumbersome, the reviews for all 400 of the 500 variations of Michael Jackson's THRILLER are grouped together with no easy way to tell many of them apart.  More, even if you know EXACTLY which one you're looking for, you can type in its' barcode and still have to go through a multistep process to get to the item page you explicitly searched for.  And the other 100 variations of Michael Jackson's THRILLER are just like stray cats with no way to distinguish between them except the ASIN which is nothing except a # that Amazon uses to identify the item in question when someone asks about it.  Except most of these ASINs are for items that were long out of print before Amazon even existed and only exist because someone created an item page for it for who knows what reason, maybe to sell it on the Amazon Marketplace, and many of these ASINs go long abandoned.  
Amazon remedies this tangled mess of a website by refunding your money no matter whose fault the issue is.  It doesn't matter if the 3rd part seller screwed up, the post office or a gremlin.  It's been refunded so all is well.  Until next time.
title: “a tangled web”

content: I have purchased many things on Amazon with no problems so far, my partner uses it almost daily and she has always had good customer service when there have been issues. I tried selling on Amazon and found it difficult to understand, I have been selling on eBay for years, don't like them but easy to use. You will find products cheaper outside Amazon, I often find the products then search the business seller name and use their website, that way you are supporting the business directly instead of huge platforms that charge sellers huge fees.

content: I have been an  Amazon prime member for about 2 or 3 years paying over 100$ a yr. for free two day shipping. Just tried to order a PRIME product that ships from the Amazon warehouse expecting it to arrive in two days. Not the case! Today is Dec.19th and product is to  to arrive Dec. 26th.Thought I should have it in two days seeing as I pay for Prime and it said two day shipping at checkout but also said arrives after Xmas Dec 26th. Spoke with a supervisor and she informed me the two day Prime shipping guarantee is from the day it is shipped and does not include the order filling process. Could  possibly take much longer than two days. She stated the guarantee is for two days from shipping date not order date.  I think folks should be aware of this Prime policy if they are not already.
title: “Prime two day shipping policy”

content:
Don't Get Me Wrong.... But I LOVE Shopping On Amazon.com. I Just HATE That They Keep On Changing There Review Policies. It Really Makes No Sense To Me At All. Because I am a person Who Really Enjoys Writing Reviews On All Types Of Products I've Try. And I Write And Say What I Mean. Rather I Like The Product or Not. And Amazon Makes It Very Hard For People Like Me To Voice Our Point Of View. On Products We Have Try and Tested. Amazon is Deleted so many People Reviews Over Some Dumb Stuff.  All They Do is just Delete With out Really Explaining Why. This is what they say:Amazon does not permit reviews from customers whose relationship to the product or seller may be perceived as biased. 

I Mean WTF Are They Talking About??? What if that person don't have a Relationship with the seller and all that BS? I Feel That Amazon is so wrong on that. And They Are Letting a lot of people go over some BS.  I've Been With Amazon For a Long Time. And I Also Pay For Amazon PRIME! And I Cant Even Write a Freaking Review or even Ask a Question on a product I wanna buy! That's BS! But Other Then All That Its a Great Site, With Many Great Deals. Just There Guidelines Suck Butt!  Oh And They Seem To Keep Going Up On There PRIME Member Ship. They Went Up Again!
title: “Super Amazing!”

content:
I must admit I have a hidden agenda. I posted two reviews and I was shocked to see a 180k views. I was angry but I never wanted to shame this company before the world like that. I think there should be a time limit on all reviews. People change and companies too. We need to forgive even as we want to be forgiven. Life happens but thanks God it is not always the end of the world, yet. So here - today I want to share a little bit of good news and common sense for all you online shoppers and people looking for that opportunity to get out of the mess you find yourselves in. We all struggle but it is when you are poor and needy and in debt that the pressures really hit home and where hopelessness tries to kill the joy of living.

Everybody knows or want to know some kind of secret to making money and to be successful. A wise man listens to counsel but too many voices will drive you mad. Do you prefer the paperless route to getting rich quick, or do you have a proper plan to prosper that will make you rich? Countless money making offers and investment opportunities floats out there both online and offline. But for your own peace of mind and safety, it is most advisable to Google search different reviews on each selected choice before signing up or buying in. Many come with that deceitful free label that stings, like a hook to the bait. Often people are invited to financial seminars to help them cope or escape their current state of affairs into a Utopia, a lifestyle of milk and honey. And like any good business, they do require you to invest time and money. And as for good farming, it is essential to prepare the soil for sowing and reaping, which may take months and even years to fully mature. But dont despair, hard work has its rewards. 

But it is in these hard times when the vulnerable and desperate are lured with fast food cash-ins and drive off scams. Most offers are so tempting it's hard to resist, and when swallowed it has that bittersweet ending. Just like, when the serpent deceived Eve with his cunning sales act. Did God really say that? Its because he doesn't want you to become like gods too. Just try it once, no one will know! And when she saw that the fruit was good to eat, she ate of the forbidden tree of knowledge of good and evil. Then she also gave to her husband, and when he took his first bite, the whole world went into a total Black-Out. And instead of becoming like gods, they got caught naked and hiding from God.

This is a clip out of the book God and Money now available. It is a world of wisdom for one happy meal. But if you really can not afford it, I will send you the ebook for free. 

https://www.amazon.com/God-Money-Andre-Cronje/dp/1985390019
title: “Fast food cash-ins and drive off scams”

content:
Why does this company expect customers to answer questions about products? 

Try to find how to reach customer service.  Time yourself until you find a link.  Once you reach them, you must stay on the phone until the problem is resolved.  You will give up most of the time and decide it's not worth it. 

Pay for Prime--2 days delivery, right?   Except when it's not.  There are so many exceptions.  Each unit of Amazon has it's own rules and you get an order together, each is shipped with different rules, and you find you didn't meet the minimums for each.  YOu must study and understand the way the company slices itself up before placing an order.   Want to know the guarantee on an item?  Good luck.

content: I don't hate Amazon but sometimes Amazon gets to involved and I am forced to put in at least 100 words to describe my shopping experience and for the first time in my life I am at a loss for words.  Mea culp? I am not blaming anyone but myself as I am the author of my own folly. Thank you~for listening. Paul

content:
Problems understanding some of the customer service reps when I call.  My 90-year-old mother had a big problem last year.  She couldn't understand the young man and requested a supervisor.  The man got upset and raised his voice, said he spoke English good, then refused to let her talk to anyone else.  She was reduced to tears.  She will no longer deal with Amazon, she even called the bank handling her credit card but they said that she had to deal directly with Amazon.  She has refused to pay another penny to Amazon and is terrified of getting another "bad guy" as she called the customer rep she had to deal with.

I have had to talk to customer service but have been very lucky with the reps I talk to...only one I had a hard time understanding, then I just got off the phone and called back, getting someone else.  This is what I would suggest when having a problem with customer service.

content: I used to love Amazon, thought they had the best prices.  However, there is so much competition that other places are just as good.  I also don't like how they raised their minimum free shipping from $25 to $35, yet if you make that amount, they don't automatically click the box "free ship" when checking out.  They click 2 day ship for a fee and you need to manually un click and look for free ship.

content: Amazon was my first online shopping experience and it was amazing. You placed your order and it arrived in a matter of days, it was exactly what you paid for w/o any worries. Then they started the Prime services , you pay $100.00 a year up front , get two day delivery, some Kindle book discounts and their TV shows . For me even though I probably spend close to a hundred in shipping , I don't want to be told to pay this amount and " you'll get better service from us !" So now if your not a Prime customer , your shipping can take days to weeks to arrive (if at all). Many times you deal with new seller's , and your order never comes. Amazon has purchased a newspaper , they've ventured into making movies , debating purchasing pharmaceutical and the one thing that got them started their losing focus on, great deals from reputable sellers and great shipping. If you stretch yourself to thin , you fall apart and their services are doing that.  I ordered an item 4 times , from 4 different seller's , it took 2 months and it never came. Amazon did refund my money back through their A-Z customer service , but all I wanted was my item ! Now after all these years of being a dedicated customer , I'm looking for another place to shop.
title: “My Online Love,  Has Now Become Very Troublesome”

content: I used them less until we got prime and now I find I order from them more. I have had issues with things not being delivered and getting refunds back but overall the items ordered do arrive and are as described. I do not think that they find the best deals for me and their search options are not helpful to narrow the search to the items you are seeking. Often I have seen that an items is advertised at a lower price than you end up paying and that is annoying. For example, you find a hat and the small size is cheap but the medium size is 2x the price of the small. There is not reason for such a price difference. Other times you see something for $4 and click on it only to find that the $4 is not an option at all and the cheapest color/size/etc is $6 for example soo.......find what you need and then still price compare.

content: Amazon is the easiest single source to shop from but all it takes is a single look at pricing history of an item to shock you. The price you pay is not consistent over time. content:
Loved Amazon for many many years.

Since Prime came along it became harder and harder as non-prime member to make purchases; to the point that I no longer make purchases from Amazon.

I have reverted to using Ebay, Walmart Online, and alternate sites for products I want which Amazon will only sell as a prime product.This is the case with any new order now. There will always be one prime item not available, unless you are prime member.

For prime members I am sure this is satisfactory. However, I can not justify prime membership.
title: “Not easy to use unless Prime member”

content:
Amazon has a lot to offer, that's for sure. However, I try not to order much that's either sold/shipped by Amazon or fulfilled by Amazon because they play too much with their shipping. 

The last few orders I placed on Amazon that were either sold/fulfilled by Amazon took longer than a week just to get shipped. Most businesses can manage to ship out in-stock items in one business day, two tops. However, I've had Amazon wait 9 business days to ship, while my order's status has said "preparing for shipment" for 4 days. As I'm not Prime member, I feel like they do this on purpose so you'll have to wait upward of a week to get your items because they know that if they ship your items out the next business day, USPS will usually deliver in about 3 days, so why pay for Prime for a one day difference?

I never have this issue when I order items sold by a third party. I've even called Amazon about why it was taking days to "prepare my shipment" but even they couldn't tell me why or even what the real status of my order was. Oddly enough, after first telling me that my order didn't go through due to a server issue to the items just not being in stock, about one hour later, my order shipped out from a city about 60 miles away from me. My order was delivered the next morning in a box that was way too big and not even taped all the way shut.

Order from trusted third-party sellers. You'll have the best experience that way if you're not a Prime member.
title: “Plays games with shipping so you'll buy Prime”

content: Hate that it doesn't ship to all countries. Wanted to send a present straight to my friends and couldn't
title: “Frozen shipping”

content: Amazon is a great website that sells things for cheap. I have ordered many things off of Amazon  and I have only had two problems with the site.  The first problem, is that I ordered an item  for a gift to my father.  In the description it told me that it was a 1000 lumen flashlight (very bright).  When I finally received it in the mail ( around a month later )  it was nowhere near 1000 lumens. It was MAYBE around 50 lumens.  We were both very disappointed considering I spent $20 on a flashlight I could buy at a gas station.  The other problem is shipping. I have ordered some items and they have came in around 3 days later and  then I have had items that have came in around 2 MONTHS later.  Overall, they are a good site but you have to watch out for false advertisement and make sure that you'll be  okay with waiting months to receive your package .
title: “Varied shipping”

content: Amazon is slower shipping since creating Amazon Prime.  If you don't have Prime it can take up to 2 weeks to receive order
title: “Slow”

content: I think Amazon is gonna change retail in a way we cannot understand. It is good for the consumer, that is without question.  But, in the end, will it be good for our economy (business'), and our culture?  I have my doubts.

content: I use amazon about once every couple months and so far I have liked it. Some prices are better than others so I have to check around to make sure I am getting a decent deal.

content: I am very much convened that amazon gives product at very low price but some of there clothing apparel does't have that much  quality as they quote.

A friend of our family ordered a Halloween costume that arrived in December. The seller was in North America too.

content:
And that flaw is shipping.  out of all the variants in Europe yes I live in a small EU country in the east Med, but most EU shops won't ship to me, so I order something on Amazon.co.uk because the other .de, .es, .fr, .it are all country specific and won't ship to Cyprus despite being closer that the UK, so I hit checkout  on a board game that costs £19 and before I hit confirm I see shipping is £49 for standard shipping!?!?!?

so until Amazon gets the shipping in Europe method down I won't be shopping here unless I absolutely need the item.  You question me back by saying well order form another site and you will see Shipping is just as expensive? my answer is sadly no this is not the case. The same board game I found on a game site from Germany and they shipped it to me for £10 DHL. so no not the same boat.
title: “Amazon has 1 flaw in Europe”

content: average service and lagging behind eBay in customer care - bought an item using FBA and really not a good service - only thing that saved them and gave 3 stars is that i bought a business on amazon and know I can do better for my customers learning from their mistakes - they did fix it in the end so 3* it is .

content: I've always been a loyal member since day one of the launch and even when they raised their membership prices I still kept being a customer. After 10 years I just recently was banned from doing reviews with no apparent reason as to why. I enjoy leaving reviews so that others can tell to buy or not to buy based on how the product worked for me and now I can't anymore voice my opinions. I will not be renewing my membership and will turn my money over to either jet.com or will use any other site than Amazon. It is bittersweet as Amazon is getting worst with hiring regular people to deliver who shouldn't be delivering to people's houses without a proper background check but it's not my business so I don't care. I value 1st amendment rights and it seems that Amazon will have non of that. So if you want competition prices by not have an opinion then go with this site.
title: “I'm torn I have to give this 3 stars”

“OK SOMETIMES BUT NOT THE BEST PRICE”

you can find just about anything on this site

title: “shopping for anything”

content: Amazon has the widest selection of goods in the world, and it usually has competitive prices. But a policy they appear to have implemented in the last year or so drags my rating well down. They seem to be trying to push people to pay for shipping (through either Prime or per-order paid shipping) by seriously degrading the free shipping. This is the way I normally order. Every order I have placed in the last year has not been shipped for at least 6 days, and usually more (my last order was 8 days ago, and it hasn't shipped yet), after I placed the order. The shipping itself is fast, always 1-2 days, so they aren't using a cheaper shipping method to save costs. But they hold your order for about a week before processing and shipping it so normally you will receive it 8-10 days after you place your order. Many other online outlets offer free shipping without this kind of delay (and some of them at about the same price for the merchandise). So Amazon is now a clearly inferior online shopping site with respect to free shipping.
title: “Much good, but shipping is a big bad spot”

content: They've sent me broken products & products that weren't mine because I didn't order said item. Wrong deliveries.
title: “Mixed order up 3 times - 3 strikes you're out!!”

content: I was a huge amazon fan and spent a lot of money there as a prime member-its getting harder to contact a human when there is a problem, the do sell everything but you have to be careful because some of their "vendors" are pretty shady-one thing they do have is a great extended warranty company "fair trade" I highly recommend them-for many things you can do better elsewhere-their grocery delivery program is a total joke unless you are a rich rock star
title: “MEH”

content: I used to love Amazon. From 2006 to 2014 we were inseparable. Then, I started having issues. Prior to 2014, 99 % of my MANY orders came via UPS. I moved into town from the rural outskirts in 2014. My orders were then predominantly coming via United States Postal Service and therein was part of the reason I down rated them in this review. Orders are frequently delivered to wrong addresses, or not delivered at all. It has been a pain.  I have begged Amazon to use UPS or FedEx for my orders. They refuse. Also, I started questioning the prices. I am not talking about the resellers, as they can price as absurdly as they wish. I mean items sold and shipped by Amazon: Dawn Dishwashing Liquid, 32.4 ounce is $3.99 in local and other online stores, but Amazon is asking $11.99 for the exact same thing. And that is just one of many examples I've found recently. I still love Amazon, but they are going to have to tighten up the ship as competition is growing. They must stop promising free shipping then charging me three times the market price. And they need to dump the USPS.
title: “Amazon is in Decline”

content: I think that they can open up to other locations around the globe as well. It would prove being an excellent opportunity because that would allow them to enhance their game. The competitive prices are attractive.
title: “They're good”

content: only slight problems with them occasionally. Usually will take care of it in a fairly quick manner though.
title: “they do o.k.”

content:
I'm a member of Prime and a routine shopper. Unfortunately, Amazon no longer has my back. The quality of goods is not consistent. They no longer back the consumer as they sell inferior products. Granted the price is low but poor quality means the consumer pays.
It's important to be careful when you select.
title: “Memories”

content: Amazon is the place I primarily go for product reviews, then buy them elsewhere.  Amazon never really seems to offer great deals unless you have Amazon Prime, in which case you would want to use it very regularly for it to become worth the yearly fee.  Once in a while, I'll find something on Amazon that has a cheaper price than eBay or other random websites I find through Google Shopping, but probably 3 out of 4 times, I find that their prices are higher than the super discounted prices you can find on eBay, and are more on par with your local department stores.  I also almost never find free shipping an option on Amazon, but you see it all the time on eBay.  The only thing Amazon has going for them is the convenience factor of buying online, and of course a ton of product reviews to narrow down what you're looking for.  Fortunately for me, I've been buying online well before Amazon became a big thing and I know of other places to grab good stuff for a fraction of the price.
title: “Hit or miss for buys, great for product reviews”

content: If it werent for that ugly bald ceo id give it a good rating. he needs to stop degrading my president. hes a propagandist globalist with dteams of ruling the usa! most things are as ordered and i give bezo bozo no credit on that!

content:
More clear directions are needed for those folks who are not quite as computer literate yet.  Otherwise, it's a wonderful
site.  I've found many items I've not been able to find
elsewhere.
title: “AMZN”

content: I've ordered a lot from Amazon over the years, used to love them, but policies have changed. Maybe just too big and don't know how to manage it. Just  yesterday  I had an order from a vendor needed to be canceled. The vendor sent an email that said no problem, I'd bought from them before. At the same time received one from Amazon saying it was shipped. On Sunday? Still have not received an answer to correct status. The main issue with Amazon though is their free shipping. You have to buy so much to qualify, an amount they raise at times. Yet if you take advantage of this your order goes to the back of the line. Not always do they meet the promised shipping date if it takes too long, they just change it. This has happened every time it seems like. It's taken up to a week before for an item to ship out when choosing free shipping, but if you use a debit card they bill you when an order placed, not when shipped as most vendors do. Vendors have an authorization when placing an order so payment guaranteed until shipped, then hard charge, but Amazon actually runs it through now when order placed. Maybe they know it may take a week to ship. They've actually acknowledged using free shipping makes it a low priority order. Only if a private vendor ships themselves does it go out faster.They're CS is apparently outsourced which at times makes it hard to communicate. Just not the same Amazon it once was.
title: “Amazon Has Changed”

content: Amazon is great but when shipping something back for a refund some times they do 3-5 different refunds amount for one transaction it's very hard to keep track and sometimes refund don't even show up
title: “Refund issus”

content: I like the prices, but unless if your using prime orders take too long to arrive. I had some items come in that were incorrect, but was able to send back free of charge and was refunded the money as soon as UPS scanned the return barcode.

content: I bought an electronic device off a seller on Amazon.  They had very little experience on Amazon but the price was right so I ordered a device.  It was charged to my credit card immediately and shipped to New York instead of Texas where I live.  Tracking in Amazon showed delivered to Texas.  Tracking in UPS showed New York.  Something very fishy about it because seller refused to respond to emails.  It took almost 3 weeks to get my refund on my credit card.  I told Amazon that this was fraud, but they seemed very unconcerned at first.  I should not had to go to as much effort as I did to get my money back.
title: “Bad experience”

content:
Two companies to beware of:
I purchased a product through EBAY from Hommee-fashion501
and decided to cancel within 10 to 15 minutes but the company refused
to cancel the order. Ebay said they would refund my money but I have not seen the refund yet or the product.
The second company is Canserin through Amazon. The product received is defective 
and it took about 5 weeks to deliver, but the company wants me to send photos of the product and the package it came in before sending a replacement. And I would have to wait another 5 weeks.  
I no longer have the option of sending pictures since uploading Safari on my Mac.
I contacted Amazon but all they can/will do is send an email to the company.
I believe both products are from China but Hommee-fashion501 has a California location. Not sure about Canserin's location.
 I will no longer purchase anything from China or from either of these companies.
title: “avoid Canserin and Home-fashion501”

content: I have requested once that amazon remove me from the email sharing- pool that sends your email to third party sellers who in turn spam your inbox with "How did we do? Do you like our product? Please leave us a positive review!" I actually responded once to one of the emails, the product was supposedly delivered on a Sunday but I did not recieve it. Then I got an email back from the third party seller stating that amazon was responsible for shipping and I would need to contact amazon about a lost product. This company just wanted a positive review for a missing purchase. If amazon is responsible for selling, acquring, and shipping the item to me, why does this third party company need my email? If I so choose to leave a review, that is my business. If Macy's foreign suppliers called you every time you left the store to ask you to go online and review the clothes you just bought, would you shop at Macy's? This should not be allowed, amazon.
title: “Hate the spamming”

content: I like stuff are they selling (almost anything my imagination can allow). But my order came to me broken. Fortunately refunds work good.

content: Several years ago I would have given them five stars, but lately they have employed waaaay too many third party sellers, many of whom are selling fake products.  I bought a shirt that said it was sold by amazon, not third party, but it was clearly a forgery.  The image provided on the website showed the picture on the shirt taking up most of the shirt, but the shirt I got had a picture about the size of a standard sheet of notebook paper, AND it was badly smeared!  I also bought some makeup from a brand I usually buy at the mall, and it was crumbly and hard, and it smelled weird.  What's frustrating is that even after contacting Amazon about these scammers, Amazon continues to let them sell their bogus products!
title: “Fake sellers and poor quality control”

When I contact them they sent my call to South Africa to resolve that problem. With my surprise, I find that African male has all my banking information through Amazon's company. It is scary!

content: At time's ordering from Amazon is simple, fast, and easy. Other times it's a huge headache full of confusing shipping charges, unusable gift cards that say there's $0 when there should be money available, and a lot of products can't be delivered to Canada, which is extra frustrating after searching for and finding a particular item only to get halfway through ordering to realize I can't get it delivered to me.

content: Since I've joined Prime, shipping is great.  My biggest issue with Amazon is that if you do not pay attention (learned the hard way) to who you are buying from you can have problems with returns and refunds.

content: I like their platform.   Easy to find things that I need.  Only thing that I don't like is their review system. If they show how many people have purchased a product with no review.  Than I can know the percentage that how many people is ok with their purchase.
title: “Good place to buy”

content: Over 10 years I have probably spent $10,000 on Amazon, especially given the photo equipment I have purchased.  They still provide fair value and a decent customer experience BUT now (I) non-prime delivery times are intentionally delayed; (Ii) the minimum purchase required for free delivery is up; and (III) pricing is no longer reliably competitive.  For many items, Jet.com provides a better experience - on all of cost, minimum purchase for free delivery and speed of delivery (in NYC, often next day.). The selection is way narrower but it offers a significantly better experience if they carry what you want.  It seems evident that these policies are designed to push customers to subscribe to Amazon Prime.  That is fair as a business model, but it may not be fair as a competitive model.
title: “Pushing Amazon Prime”

content:
For the most part I have had a great experience with Amazon with the exception of an unscrupulous watch merchant who advertised their Invicta Watch for $1200 but when it arrived they had left the tag on that stated the watch was only worth 
$229. I tried to fight this as fraudulent but could get nowhere with Amazon. So I was a bit PO
title: “LOVE THIS SITE”

content: Amazon customer service is good.  They have generally refunded, replaced and apologised in a timely way when required.  The reason I look elsewhere before buying from them is the way they treat their employees.  We have all seen news items about conditions in their fulfillment centres, many of us know a self-employed driver who has been driven mad and had to throw in the towel.  Some of us have seen their employment contracts, or the contracts their chosen temp agencies impose.  Basically, if you're a potential customer they love and respect you, but if you're a worker they exploit you.  Now, a bit of a dogleg here admittedly, but it occurred to me that they sell lots of music, film, books etc.. The creative souls who make this stuff can get famous, they can get knighted, they can work in TV, radio, the media, they win awards AND THEY OFTEN HAVE LIFE STYLES THAT INCLUDE LOTS OF BOOZE AND DRUGS, but if you wanna work for them and you've had a happy fag in the last six months you can get lost.  Hypocrisy.  And horrible hubris.  Look somewhere else first.  Just USE Amazon like they USE people.
title: “Amazon customer service is good.  Shame they don't favour their employees with same level of care.”

content: I shop at Amazon.com because it has such a variety of choices of products.  However, that same variety means that they deal with a large number of venders, and follow-up on damaged or missing packages is almost non-existent.  Sometimes the person responsible for delivery puts the package in the mailbox (which is against the law).  That means I have to get to the mailbox before the postman does.  If the postman sees the package in the mailbox before I do, the package is confiscated and I have to pay postage on it - again!  I have tried several ways of trying to contact Amazon.com about this problem and have been ignored.  The one time they did respond, they told me the company supplying the product had gone out of business and they could not do anything to help me.
title: “Good variety, poor follow-up”

content: I have order some things on Amazon, I dont use Amazon as much as Ebay because it takes long time to find out if the shop in Amazon really ship overseas or to what countries, would be nice, u can see it in beginning as ebay and not after 10 clicks

content: OK some sellers don't respond to your email but amazon customer service step in and sort the issue out.

content: I mainly just publish comic strip books for free with them now. Although you can generate 70 % of what you charge for your books in sales by choosing the 70-percent option for the $2.99-$9.99 range, overall sales have plummeted for me here the last four years plus they don't provide your views tally; consequently, I had to move most of my books to another market. On the bright side, you can possibly get a $1500 advance by using their Kindle Scout program as a member; however, your submission must have at least 50,000 words and fall into a certain category. Minus getting a sale, you will generate revenue for each page of one of your books that someone reads on their Kindle but it is usually pennies literally. I give them strong credit for publishing your submission within 12 hours.
title: “Whether to write books for Amazon's digital text platform program”

content: I recently ordered two laptop bags from Amazon India but finally they delivered only one. Once I contacted them, I got to know that their vendor shipped only one, and they refunded my money. It was ok to get the money back but that was not what I wanted, I wanted 2 bags.

content:
True, you can find just about anything at Amazon, as well as an amazing variety of things, but shipping costs are so high, and many times you need to go through the purchasing sequences to find out what exactly the shipping charges will be. And should you want to contact the sell, you need to DIG to find their contact info!
Lately, more and more sellers aren't even in the USA, something you might not find out until after the purchase. 
I wish Amazon was more transparent with providing information.

content: but customer service is not so ideal. You are basically on your own. You don't know where some of the stuff comes from. One order took almost 3 months to arrive .. found out they had to ship it all the way from china

content: Since Amazon attempts to be a one-stop shop, you don't always get the best. Third party vendors make it more difficult to shop for or return items because each seller has different policies regarding shipping. It's not all upfront, and the appearance of the Amazon site doesn't change when you pick items from vendors versus Amazon. Like there's no signal that says, "Hey, you're buying from Amazon, you're buying from BooksAhoy, CrapShoesAlabama, and ConnorY1983. Is that ok? They will charge you for shipping, they will charge you to return the items you buy, and these guys ARE NOT fulfilled by Amazon." Also, Amazon desperately wants you to be a Prime Member, raising the cost of free shipping from $25 to $35 to $49. Now, that doesn't include books, either. You have to spend $25 on books alone to get free shipping on books. And still find stuff adding to $49 to get free shipping on the entire order, that is if you don't have Prime. It's just not customer-friendly anymore.
title: “Not Customer-friendly”

content: Amazon Prime used to ship via UPS. When the switched to using USPS, they made a big mistake in meeting the needs of their customers. I purchase ALOT from Amazon. Their prices can be good (not always) but for me it saves time and it's convenient. Or at least it used to be. I live in a rural town in a heavily populated county. USPS delivers mail to mailboxes on the street, not door to door. Even with a large mailbox, packages don't fit. The 2 day shipping turns to 5 days because I have to travel to the Post Officeto pick up packages.  It's an easy 20 minutes each way to pick up packages between 9-5:00 ( if there is no commute traffic to deal with.). That doesn't work when a person is employed. UPS delivers to my door, but not USPS. My Prime membership comes with other perks; such as free movie streaming. I can't use any of the other perks because of having Satelite Internet and data limits. I'll continue to use Amazon because of the size of their selections and and the ease of ordering. I hate that they use USPS and if there was a better alternative to Amazon, I'd take it.
title: “Amazon made a big mistake with customer service when they changed their Amazon Prime shipping”

content:
Amazon.com prices are going up and up... Why?

I've been shopping on Amazon.com for more than a decade now. However, in the last couple of years, their prices have been surging up well above the manufacturer's suggested retail price (MSRP) on many items. It used to be that they had the lowest prices on most anything. Now, that is not the case and I am very leery when I shop on Amazon.com 

Just this week, I walked through retail shops like Bed, Bath and Beyond, (certainly not a bargain store) and checked prices on Amazons site on my smartphone while in the shop. I found BBBs prices (before discount) were significantly lower (40% lower on some items) than Amazon's best "prime members only" prices. Yes, Amazon's price was nearly double the price of some items at BBB. Every item I looked at was priced lower than the best Amazon.com's price from any seller thereon. And again, that is before factoring in a 20% added discount at BBB.  

When I go to some manufacturer's websites, I find their MSRP is significantly lower than Amazon's best prices. For example, just today I found the Navy Sport-Brella Versa-Bella priced at $26 on Amazon.com when it can be purchased directly from the manufacturer for $20. That same umbrella is available at many other retail stores and websites for the same $20, but Amazon.com wants an extra 30% above MSRP.  Why???

And now with Amazon's $49 minimum for free shipping, I am looking at other options and away from their greed-driven ways. I understood when it went from $25 to $35 (times change; shipping costs go up). But then it jumped to $49 in no time. While other companies are lowering their minimum purchase for free shipping, Amazon is raising theirs. 

Frankly, with Amazon.com's jacked-up prices, it's getting harder and harder to find $50 worth of items that I want on their website that I can't get elsewhere for less money.

What happened, and why such a significant greed-driven shift in the last year or two, Amazon? How much profit is really enough, Mr. Bezos???

My suggestion to other shoppers: Do what Im now doing Check and compare prices in local retail shops and/or on other websites before you buy from Amazon.com. While Amazons prices are still better on some items, their prices on other items may give you severe sticker shock. In the end you may be surprised to learn that Amazon.com is not the bargain store it used to be.
title: “Amazon.com Prices Going UP, UP UP!!!”

content:
I PURCHASED AN ITEM FOR MY DAUGHTER'S BIRTHDAY:
THE WEBSITE SHOWED:
Guaranteed delivery date: Sept. 29, 2016 If you order in the next 17 hours and 33 minutes (Details)   Items shipped from Amazon.com 

Char-Broil TRU-Infrared Patio Bistro Electric Grill, Graphite 
$139.59 FREE Shipping for Prime members 
Sold by:Amazon.com LLC 

Choose your Prime delivery option: Thursday, Sept. 29   FREE Standard Shipping 

In Stock. 
Want it Thursday, Sept. 29? Order within 17 hrs 32 mins and choose Standard Shipping at checkout. Details 

MY MAIN PROBLEM WAS THAT, ONCE I ACTUALLY ORDERED THE ITEM, IT THEN SHOWED THAT THE ITEM WOULD NOT BE DELIVERED UNTIL FRIDAY, SEPT 30 ..!!

I CALLED AMAZON AND SPOKE TO 4 DIFFERENT PEOPLE IN CUSTOMER SERVICE.  EACH ONE TOLD ME THAT THIS DID NOT MAKE SENSE TO THEM EITHER BUT THAT THEY WERE UNABLE TO UPGRADE THE DELIVERY OR SPEED THE DELIVERY IN ANY WAY AND MY ITEM WOULD STILL NOT BE DELIVERED UNTIL SEPT. 30 - EVEN THOUGH THE WEBSITE SHOWS "GUARANTEED DELIVERY DATE OF SEPT 29"
NONE OF THE 4 PEOPLE COULD EXPLAIN WHAT THE WORD "GUARANTEED" MEANT IN THIS INSTANCE, NOR WOULD ANY OF THEM OFFER ANY SORT OF COMPENSATION FOR THIS 'FALSE ADVERTISING' ..  
ONE REP TOLD ME THAT IF MY DAUGHTER HAD ORDERED IT DIRECTLY THEN SHE MIGHT HAVE RECEIVED IT BY 09-29 ..  AND THAT IF I HAD ORDERED IT FOR MYSELF, I MIGHT HAVE RECEIVED IT BY 09-29 ..  THIS DID NOT MAKE ANY SORT OF SENSE TO ME WHATSOEVER .. ?!
THE LAST REP (SUPPOSEDLY SOME SORT OF SUPERVISOR) TOLD ME THAT EVEN THOUGH THE WORDING SAID "GUARANTEED DELIVERY DATE ... ... " SUDDENLY HER WEBSITE SHOWED THAT THE EARLIEST DELIVERY DATE WAS NOW 09-30 ..  EVEN THOUGH I WAS LOOKING DIRECTLY AT THE WEBSITE AT THAT MOMENT AND MY SCREEN STILL SHOWED 09-29 .. ?!?!?

I ASKED HER FOR AN UPPER ESTABLISHMENT PERSON TO DISCUSS THIS MATTER WITH AND SHE TOLD ME THAT CUSTOMER SERVICE WAS THE ONLY PLACE I COULD TALK TO TO AT ALL ..    IT IS QUITE APPARENT THAT THIS PROBLEM WILL NEVER BE RESOLVED OR CORRECTED AND THAT CUSTOMERS CANNOT TRUST THE AMAZON WEBSITE TO BE CORRECT ..  THIS IS QUITE DISTURBING, AS I HAVE BEEN A REGULAR CUSTOMER OF AMAZON FOR YEARS.. AT THIS POINT, I AM BEYOND FRUSTRATED ..
title: “DON'T BELIEVE THE "GUARANTEED" DELIVERY DATES ..”

content:
My biggest issue with Amazon is the reviews. 

The have paid reviewers at the top of the lists. Don't see a conflict with someone being paid to review a product? 

They lump all reviews for similar models, some models are vastly different in specs and configuration. You could have one model that is great and another model that is a POS but Amazon lumps them together and you don't know until someone posts a model number in their review. You will think a item is great when it is known to be defective. Amazon is well aware of this issue but will not do anything about it.

Don't ever use Amazon Services. First off, Amazon techs are subcontractors, nothing more. We have never set foot in a Amazon facility. Amazon does not actually vet their technicians. They have changed policies so many times due to techs going onsite drunk/high and stealing/breaking things at customers sites. I don't doubt that Amazon fixes all the issues but some items are not replaceable. Issues with businesses quoting one price then jacking it up when they get onsite.

Amazon returns are great, Customer service is great IF YOU USE THE PHONE. Email support is terrible, just like everyone else. Cut and paste responses that have no bearing on your issue.
title: “Good prices on products but everything else is meh”

content:
To be fair to Amazon, books are great through this source. I got some great editions of Kant and Sartre through this site. However, fellow movie collectors: beware. I have coveted Raise The Red Lantern for ages. Try getting it from the two mail order movie sites like MU. Amazon promised me a pristine new copy for a king's ransom, I paid close to fifty bucks for a single movie, I know, stop laughing, when it arrived it looked like a whole drawer's worth of silverware had fallen on it. The circular scratches covered it completely, I never play the return game, in Amazon's defense, perhaps they would have corrected it. Unfortunately and, conveniently coincidentally, it just happened to be the last 'new' one they had. Now you see why I didn't try, don't you? 
   If this was the 'brand new' one, imagine what the 'used' ones looked like? I have had three orders of philosophical works that were all excellent. I simply need to share with fellow movie collectors that this was the single worst looking fifty dollar 'brand new' disc that I have ever seen. Three players would not play this movie, I would stick to other items besides DVDs. In Amazon's defense, both mail order movie houses are notorious for sending other people's returns out as new movies. I dropped one of them for consistently mailing me unplayable, scratched beyond repair discs. I did take offense at the adjectives 'brand new' 'never been played,' this disc looked worse than movies I have owned for over a decade. Stick To Other Items. Take Care. Deus Vobiscum.  Q.E.D.
title: “Greatly Variant In Reliability”

content: Anybody who believes that Amazon doesn't have counterfeit vendors are in for a shock.  THEY DO!!!  I have read about Amazon's counterfeit problem but didn't want to believe it existed.  I do now that I have purchased counterfeit cosmetics and a Isaac Mizrahi bag.  Back in March I purchased what I thought was an Isaac Mizrahi bag.  I was saving it for the summer.  I received it and thought it looked nice but didn't thoroughly examine it.  When I finally looked at the bag...Isaac Mizrahi does not stamp his bag in cheap gold ink.  The bag wasn't even leather.  By the time it was uncovered...it was too late to get refunded.  I also have bought counterfeit lipsticks. I did 2 things.  I went to YouTube on how to spot the fakes and it all matched up.  I had a family friend who is a manager at an Ulta cosmetics store confirm this too.  I would not have suspected an inexpensive makeup brand like NYX to have counterfeits buy unfortunately they do.  I was refunded but that's not the point.  I was going to order an Anastasia Beverly Hills contour palette at $45 ...$5 more than they charge at Sephora.  I read at least 5 reviews that said they received a counterfeit and one person uploaded a photo of the color swatches of the real vs the fake.  They are charging $5 more for a counterfeit item.  Amazon has some good deals and some things are overpriced.  I will still order from them but am limited to what I buy from there after reading the counterfeit reviews and experiencing this with some of their items myself.
title: “Not as good as they previously were. Counterfeit items.”

content: I bought a Leatherman 830040 New Wave Multi-Tool With Nylon Sheath +Leatherman 42 Piece Tool Steel Bit Kit + Removable Pocket Clip & Quick-Release Lanyard Ring + Cleaning Cloth and in the description it indicated; and the new bronze bushing makes one-handed knife access a smooth operation ... what I received was the Leatherman Wave 2H, meaning 2 hands operation, not one handed. Picture did not have the 2H on the tool. Packaging was previously opened and re-taped. I destroyed the packaging and cannot return. Frustrating.
title: “Amazon is good, but research each purchase before hand”

content:
Obviously Amazon is huge, one of the largest internet retailers, so your not going to be able to avoid using them.

But I think they have really gone down in quality over the last few years, especially on the shipping front, when buying direct from Amazon.
They often will not even ship days before your estimated delivery time.
You apparently now have to "pay" to get fast service from amazon in the form of prime.. whereas if you instead buy from any vendor on ebay and you get fast shipping for free.
